story: Consider Him Outreach Ministries was established in June 2009. It was created by high school girls for high school girls. It began as a bible study between five girls who soon felt a call to do more. We have grown from holding events with nine people in attendance all the way to over forty people in attendance. Through all of the growth, we have remained true as a Christian ministry devoted to providing a safe atmosphere where girls can have fun, develop healthy friendships, and grow in their relationship with God. Our main way of reaching the girls in our community is by hosting monthly events called GNO’s (Girls’ Night Out) as well as summer retreats each year. Our retreats are currently being held at the group lodge at Cloudland Canyon State Park. They are an incredible time for girls to take a break from reality and spend time in nature soaking up God’s word.  We bring in speakers and worship leaders and have incredible adult chaperones to invest in the lives of the girls. Our overall desire as a ministry through every event we hold is always to make an impact on our community by making Christ’s name known. We invite you and encourage you to be praying for our ministry and support us in whatever way you see fit. The only way we have been able to make it through the past four years has been by the grace of God and through the support of those around us. We are so grateful for every prayer, donation, and word of encouragement we have ever received and we hope that we will continue to show our gratitude.
story_txt: Consider Him Outreach Ministries was established in June 2009. It was created by high school girls for high school girls. It began as a bible study between five girls who soon felt a call to do more. We have grown from holding events with nine people in attendance all the way to over forty people in attendance. Through all of the growth, we have remained true as a Christian ministry devoted to providing a safe atmosphere where girls can have fun, develop healthy friendships, and grow in their relationship with God. Our main way of reaching the girls in our community is by hosting monthly events called GNO’s (Girls’ Night Out) as well as summer retreats each year. Our retreats are currently being held at the group lodge at Cloudland Canyon State Park. They are an incredible time for girls to take a break from reality and spend time in nature soaking up God’s word.  We bring in speakers and worship leaders and have incredible adult chaperones to invest in the lives of the girls. Our overall desire as a ministry through every event we hold is always to make an impact on our community by making Christ’s name known. We invite you and encourage you to be praying for our ministry and support us in whatever way you see fit. The only way we have been able to make it through the past four years has been by the grace of God and through the support of those around us. We are so grateful for every prayer, donation, and word of encouragement we have ever received and we hope that we will continue to show our gratitude.

story:
Imagine you have nothing to eat, no running water, no electricity, no sewage? Imagine that you have to walk for hours in the heat to fetch water, wait on long lines, and sometimes come home without any? Imagine you have to run from village to village, sometimes having to walk for three months to run away from rebels who are burning your village, pillaging, raping the women and young girls, and killing the men?

 

We have witnessed, heard and seen these and much more.

We are a team of conscientious integrative healers who are trained in the 7-Step Humanitarian Integrative Healing Model at the Association for Trauma Outreach and Prevention (ATOP) Meaningfulworld, an international humanitarian organization affiliated with the United Nations, and have decided to do something about this situation. We had already worked in Africa for over 5 years, working in Sierra Leone, Kenya, Rwanda, and DR Congo.
 
We have no overhead. ATOP/Meaningful World is all volunteer and self funded so 100% of your donation is used for the outreach missions. 
 
Funds will be used for:
- Training local health workers and psychologists and brothers and sisters who serve those in need
- Healing workshops utilizing the Seven Step Model for locals recovery from trauma from  events and/or everyday life (ie genocide in Rwanda)
- Airfare for volunteers
- Food on missions
- Basic accommodations
- Local transportation
- Sports equipment and games for children
- Notebooks and pens
- Purified water
 

Volunteers are trained in the Seven Step Integrative Healing Model developed by Dr. Ani Kalayjian.  We give our time, our love and our effort in challenging situations.   We need your help.  Please donate.
 
We are returning this year to Kenya, Rwanda and DR Congo, to continue the healing circles, the peace building workshops, empowering lectures and training programs conducted in the past several years. We work with the youth giving them tools, hope and guidance, we work with the women empowering them and transforming their trauma, we are working with the older adults, giving them tools for self healing, encouraging them to find a new meaning in their last stage of development, we are working with the men, to empower them help them transform their generational trauma.
 
We unfortunately do not have video footage from our previous mission to Kenya, Rwanda or the DR Congo which is why the posted video above is from a mission done to Sierra Leone.
 
Thankfully, this year Haik Kocharian, an award winning filmmaker and photographer will join us to photograph our journey  that you too can witness the bulging eyes of famine, the bloated bellies of malnutrition, the hopeless gaze of a mother who cannot feed her child, and the despair in the father who cannot save his family.  You will see how your support is giving them hope, is transforming their sorrow and despair, how they feel empowered learning new tools for healing, transforming trauma into meaning and resilience, learning sustainability, and Emotional Intelligence.  You will witness the smiles in their faces, the gratitude in their hearts, the humble celebration of you.

 

Your support will multiply and we will be as Meaningfulworld Ambassadors, your agents working with you to deliver your conscientious donations to Africa to make a difference in lives of thousands of innocent people who are suffering in vain. Come join our journey by sending us your donation now, any amount is not too little, as you are giving from your heart, as we know you want to be part of the change you want to see

 

On June 29th we will be going on a mission to Kenya, Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo.  We will be repeating the same trip that was done in previous years and all of us at Meaningfulworld kindly need your help to make it happen! 


Association for Trauma Outreach & Prevention (ATOP) at Meaningfulworld, founded in 1990, a charitable NGO affiliated with the United Nations has achieved recognition as a leader in training humanitarian outreach professionals around the world in over 40 countries. ATOP has been working in Africa in Sierra Leone, Kenya, Rwanda, and DR Congo. This is the 3rd mission to Kenya bringing mind-body-eco awareness, mindfulness, meditation, energy balancing, peace building, conflict transformation, leadership, and restorative justice. www.meaningfulworld.com

 

MEANINGFULWORLD AFRICA TEAM OF 2013

TEAM LEADER:

Dr. Ani Kalayjian is a graduate of Teachers College, Columbia University with Masters and Doctoral degrees. As a pioneering multilingual therapist, educator, United Nations Consultant over the past 20 years, traumatologist, genocide scholar, director and author, she has devoted her life to bringing healing to those who have survived the devastation of disaster, whether human-made or natural.  Her 7-step Integrative Healing Model has been used in over thirty countries globally to transform the trauma into healing, through mindfulness, forgiveness and meaning-making. She has 4 internationally acclaimed books on Disaster & Mass Trauma, Chief Editor of an international book on Forgiveness & Reconciliation: Psychological pathways to conflict transformation and peace building (Springer Publishing, 2009, paperback 2010), and Chief Editor of II Volumes on Emotional Healing around the World: Rituals and practices for resilience and meaning-making (Greenwood, ABC-CLIO, 2010), a CD on Ancestral Healing Meditation (in 4 languages). 

TEAM MEMBERS:

Victoria Alexander is an ambitious young lady who enjoys working and learning from other people. She hold a BA in Psychology from the University at Buffalo and is applying to masters programs for next year. Victoria comes from a multicultural family: Spanish, Greek and Italian.  She loves to meet new people and finds it important to learn about cultures other than her own.  She works full time as a Research Data Associate at the NYU Medical Center in the Psychiatry department studying PTSD in NYC Police Officers as well as veterans of Vietnam, Iraq and Afghanistan. Ultimately she wishes to work as a Clinical Psychologist studying behavior differences among various cultures.

Rita Alexander: Rita Pisani Alexander is a native New Yorker who derives great satisfaction serving New York City's neediest patients as a registered pharmacist.   She has worked for over 33 years in a hospital in Queens, New York.  She has received honors at Queens Hospital regarding her work and dedication to the critical care unit (adult and neonatal) as a pharmacist.  Mrs. Alexander  has degrees from New York University (BA) and St. John's University (BS).  Her  Italian-born parents were World War 1 and World War 2 survivors who instilled strong family values in Rita and her brother.  She has volunteered in nursing homes and public schools.

Leysa Cerswell: MA Psychology candidate at The New School for Social Research (NSSR). Working alongside communities in rural Kenya and with youth leaders in China, Kuwait, Mexico, Canada, and the US, inspires my commitment to social justice work. I work with Greenhope Services for Women, an alternative to incarceration residential treatment centre supporting women with addiction. My research aims to address issues and concerns relevant to populations that are underserved or marginalized in mental health care. I also assess the effectiveness of Mindfulness-based therapies with marginalized populations.

Haik Kocharian: Born in Armenia, Kocharian has lived in New York City since 1993.  He began his studies at the Armenian Theater Academy and continued his education studying film directing and photography at Brooklyn College. Mr. Kocharian’s solo exhibitions in New York City include Galerie Mourlot in 2006, Robin Rice Gallery in 2007, 92 Y Tribeca in 2009 and James Cohan Gallery in 2010. Among other awards, Mr. Kocharian was a finalist in the Smithsonian Magazine Annual Photo Competition. He collaborates with various not-for-profit NGO’s: African Services Committee, Chodron Foundation, Self Help Africa and Faiths for Safe Water. Mr. Kocharian has written and directed six short films including "Charlie," which won the Thirteen/WNET Reel 13 Shorts competition in 2007 and was broadcast on Channel 13. In 2007, he wrote and co-produced his first feature, "Manhattan Romance," a French-American production starring Isild Le Besco and Jean Mark Barr.  His new feature film “Please Be Normal,” starring Sam Waterston, Elisabeth Waterston, Louis Cancelmi and Dana Eskelson, will be released this year 2013.

In past years ATOP Team Members traveled to Kenya, Rwanda and DR Congo.  This year the trip will be repeated, but we need your help...

In 2012, ATOP members spent weeks, healing and spreading peace among trauma survivors.  This year will be no different.

NAIROBI, KENYA 2012

The ATOP Team began working in Nairobi, Kenya, with the following groups that partner with Benjamin Mwenda, Managing Director of Youth Volunteer for Change:


1. We worked with the Kwangware Women’s Group. In the largest slum of Africa, about 20 women gathered to share their experiences, stresses of life, and issues with the extreme alcoholism of their spouses. Participants engaged in energetic healing and were given tools for everyday survival and ways to engage in approaching the addiction issue as a disease, as a
social outcome of unemployment, and as a cultural resignation for not being able to provide for their families. The women reported that they benefited greatly from the new tools and wereinvigorated with energetic balance. They shared how they will continue meeting even after the ATOP Team’s departure. Garments and rings were given to the participants as tokens of
gratitude, acknowledgment, and love.


2. We then worked with the Kibera Small Business Women’s Group, also in the slum area. Here 25 participants were given leadership skills and stress-reduction mindfulness breathing exercises, as well as Reiki energetic healing. The women said that they learned not to keep
angry and aggressive thoughts or deeds to themselves. They also learned to process their feelings peacefully, release their anger and revenge, and transform their anger through forgiveness. One woman said, “I was fighting with my coworker before this training, and the entire time during the training I was thinking of going back and continuing the fight. But now that I learned a healthier way, through emotional intelligence, I am going to let go and practice forgiveness.”


3. We then moved to the children’s group, where 75 children were gathered and excited to greet the ATOP Team. The Four Agreements were shared to provide a framework for how to live a stress-free life, as was Martin Luther King’s Non-Violent Communication (NVC) for preventing conflicts. In addition, energetic healing, yoga, and chakra balancing exercises were taught in combination with ethnic songs and dance, which they said was very fun and a learning process.


4. We then worked with the Kibera Youth Volunteers for Change. This was another lively workshop of 25 young people ages 17 to 29. The Four Agreements, life processing, and emotional intelligence were shared, and NVC was reviewed and applied to their challenging personal cases. One of the cases that resonated with all the participants was how to deal with a
friend who tries to take your girlfriend. This session was followed by meditation and mindfulness breathing techniques.


5. A two-day training was given in Mathare, also in the slum area, to 22 former gang members. Here developing emotional intelligence and NVC were shared as well as the importance of the circle of dialogue.


6. On July 1 the ATOP Team took part in the Maranatha Church services in Kwangware, a Pentecostal Church, and both team members gave sermons on love, forgiveness, and restorative vision of justice to over 700 congregation members.


7. The ATOP Team worked with Karika aging group in Kawangare (the slums), where more than 90 women and men (ages 60 to 90) gathered to learn mindfulness and breath exercises for health, reducing blood pressure, and reducing physical pain. The motto was “old is gold.” A generational group was recommended as well as essential oils and an ongoing practice of limbic
breath. After the workshop the aged attendees shared that they felt much better, experiencing less physical pain, more inner peace, and more meaning in life.

 

8. On July 2, partnering with Bikundo Onyari, CEO of aNDE Kenya, we held a workshop with lawyers, paralegals, and prison warders in Halinguni. More than 25 attorneys, paralegals, and other prison personnel gathered with eagerness and insight to better their lives. Participants shared that
this was the most helpful training they had ever experienced, in which all of the teachings were in line with their needs, such as how to manage anger in themselves and in those they work with, how to let go and practice forgiveness, and how to open their energy centers for optimum health and
flow of vital energy – especially the throat and the heart centers to also alleviate the hypothyroidism and heart palpitations that were often expressed.

 

9. The ATOP Team was invited by the Office of the Vice-Chancellor and the Dean and the Chair of the Psychology Department to give a workshop at the University of Nairobi. More than 135 4 students, faculty, and staff gathered and had a transformative experiential session that revealed what trauma does in the body, mind, emotions, and spirit, as well as the restorative
ways to cope with it. Although at first they were uncomfortable with physical expressions of love, at the end of the workshop they were exhibiting such transformative behavior and did not leave the auditorium without hugging and giving one another their unconditional love and regard. Future collaborative plans were made for the following year for longer all-day
workshops. Dr. Kariuki, the Chairperson of the Psychology Department said: “It was our joy and pleasure to have met your team. Many thanks for reassuring us and our students that indeed forgiveness, reconciliation and resilience are possible and that each one of us has a role to play. We hope that we can work out longer collaboration and linkages in workshops and
seminars in order to fully participate in the healing of our world.”

 

10. At the Rosa Mystical Center, partnering with Eunice Olawo, Director of MA-Counseling Studies, the ATOP Team was invited to conduct a workshop especially for psychologists, counselors, directors of counseling centers, and mental health professionals. The Seven-Step Integrative Model was shared and practiced, the theoretical rationale and foundation were elaborated upon, an in-depth discussion took place, an introduction to restorative justice and
ways to enhance the work of mental health professionals was presented, and essential oils from Young and Living were introduced and applied for ultimate grounding. This was followed by the experiential session in open nature, the Center’s garden. Participants shared that although they never thought they would resume positions as “secret prayer” and the “worrier pose,” they felt so much lighter, happier, more grounded, and loving. Their backaches and
shoulder pains melted away with their positive affirmation and movements.

 

Kigali, Rwanda


Our mission to Rwanda took place in collaboration with Aloys Ntezimana, Director of the NGO Self-Employed Youth Organization (SEYO), and Steven Shyaka, Mentee of the
Strongest Oak in Kigali. On 4th of July, the ATOP Team met with Nyilinhwaya Faustin, the Minister of Gender and Family Promotion in Rwanda. Although it was a national holiday –
Independence Day for Rwanda, a date it shares with the U.S. Independence Day – and all offices were closed, he made a special effort to open his office for our team. He presented us with an update of women’s issues and he elaborated on the recent improvements in gender issues such as the minimum of 50 percent of women required in the parliament. He also shared the
ongoing challenges, such as national policy against gender violence, high levels of gender-based violence (GBV), limited knowledge of laws by women, persistence of some negative cultural beliefs such as female genital mutilation (FGM) – which they don’t acknowledge as mutilation because they don’t cut the clitoris but rather stretch both labia for what they believe is the
ultimate pleasure for both men and women – as well as rapes of domestic workers. He also emphasized their commitment to the United Nations Millennium Development Goals (MDG)-3,
which aims to promote gender equality and empower women while seeking to eradicate gender-based violence, which is an impediment to gender equality and sustainable development. He also emphasized the need for psychological support and ended by inviting our team to conduct workshops in collaboration with his office. 

The next day we conducted a workshop at the Youth Employment Generation office in Nyagatare, which is affiliated with the Rwanda Minister of Youth and engages in reproductive
health, HIV education, sewing and other vocational trainings, and nurturing entrepreneurship.

The goals of this agency are peacebuilding, patriotism, national reconciliation, and sustainable development. We had more than 100 participants. Unfortunately, 44.9 percent Rwandese are
living below the poverty line, and the majority are young people. Principles of conflict transformation, emotional intelligence, forgiveness, and restorative justice were introduced
and reinforced, and this was followed by chakra balancing, energetic healing exercises, essential oils, and Bach flower remedies. Attendees were given bookmarks with non-violent
communication (NVC) messages, as well as earrings. We then were transported via motorcycles to the Youth Business Center. There were 48 men and women attending this workshop, and we
shared the Seven Habits of Highly Effective Leaders (Steven Covey, 1998), emotional intelligence, work ethics, and values. The team was joined by Michele Merkel, MS, and Stu Merkel, MPH, MBA; their contribution was extremely valuable, especially because of the addition of the male perspective in leadership.

DR CONGO

Few countries have seen the amount of violence that the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has seen in the past decades. Since 1996 the fourth largest African state has seen wars with its neighbors, civil wars, and other forms of violence that have proliferated immense poverty and famine, an AIDS/HIV epidemic, increasing rape rates and gender intolerance. The International Rescue Committee estimated that over 5.4 million people have died from the prolonged conflict, that Nicholas D. Kristof of the New York Times says is being “ignored” by the international community. The vicious cycle of hate and fear seems almost unbreakable for the citizens of the DRC.

Our organization,　The Association for Trauma Outreach & Prevention　(ATOP) of Meaningful World, a New York based international organization affiliated with DPI of the United Nations, devoted to fostering a, just, peaceful, and meaningful world, has collaborated with many organizations to bring rehabilitation programs to Sierra Leone in March of 2009, and over 29 other humanitarian empowerment, educational, and rehabilitation programs around the world including Haiti. Our mission to DR Congo will focus on the city of Bukavu, home to nearly half a million people, including 500 displaced children. We are collaborating with the Peace Center there, as well as Université de la Paix, refugee centers, and hospitals in the area. We will be working with vulnerable groups of children, women who were raped in the war, refugees and older adults. We have the experience and expertise to make a difference. ATOP team members that will be traveling to Congo are: Dr. Ani Kalayjian – Founder and President of ATOP. Dr. Kalayjian has devoted her life to bringing healing to those who have survived the devastation of disaster. Dr Isidore A. Udoh is a postdoctoral fellow at the HIV Center for Clinical and Behavioral Studies at the New York State Psychiatric Institute and Columbia University, and Jennifer De Mucci – Vice President of ATOP, holds a Master’s degree in psychology.

Our goals are to help survivors heal their emotional and psychospiritual wounds resulting from years of armed conflict, poverty, discrimination, and displacement. We aim to help surviving communities understand the impact of the past on their present through education, healing groups, and self-healing. We will train psychologist, social workers, nurses and other health care practitioners. This helps create educated and healthy communities that are able to transform generationally transmitted trauma by cultivating a new world view, train and educate high school teachers and students to nurture non-violence in their respective communities, and foster communal dialogue for conflict transformation and peace-building through practicing forgiveness. We also plan to help mobilize communities, facilitating healthy partnerships that build bridges of diversity through common values centered on the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

We need your generous spirit! Please help us make a difference in in the lives of hundreds of people. Your generous donations are vital to make this ATOP of Meaningfulworld humanitarian outreach project a success. Our first team will depart June 29th 2013.

Alternative ways to donate...

Donations can be made via check or Pay-Pal (see www.meaningfulworld.com for more details). Checks should be made out to ATOP and mailed to ATOP 135 Cedar St, Cliffside Park, NJ 07010.

8. On July 2, partnering with Bikundo Onyari, CEO of aNDE Kenya, we held a workshop with lawyers, paralegals, and prison warders in Halinguni. More than 25 attorneys, paralegals, and other prison personnel gathered with eagerness and insight to better their lives. Participants shared that this was the most helpful training they had ever experienced, in which all of the teachings were in line with their needs, such as how to manage anger in themselves and in those they work with, how to let go and practice forgiveness, and how to open their energy centers for optimum health and flow of vital energy – especially the throat and the heart centers to also alleviate the hypothyroidism and heart palpitations that were often expressed.
 
9. The ATOP Team was invited by the Office of the Vice-Chancellor and the Dean and the Chair of the Psychology Department to give a workshop at the University of Nairobi. More than 135 4 students, faculty, and staff gathered and had a transformative experiential session that revealed what trauma does in the body, mind, emotions, and spirit, as well as the restorative ways to cope with it. Although at first they were uncomfortable with physical expressions of love, at the end of the workshop they were exhibiting such transformative behavior and did not leave the auditorium without hugging and giving one another their unconditional love and regard. Future collaborative plans were made for the following year for longer all-day workshops. Dr. Kariuki, the Chairperson of the Psychology Department said: “It was our joy and pleasure to have met your team. Many thanks for reassuring us and our students that indeed forgiveness, reconciliation and resilience are possible and that each one of us has a role to play. We hope that we can work out longer collaboration and linkages in workshops and seminars in order to fully participate in the healing of our world.”
 
10. At the Rosa Mystical Center, partnering with Eunice Olawo, Director of MA-Counseling Studies, the ATOP Team was invited to conduct a workshop especially for psychologists, counselors, directors of counseling centers, and mental health professionals. The Seven-Step Integrative Model was shared and practiced, the theoretical rationale and foundation were elaborated upon, an in-depth discussion took place, an introduction to restorative justice andways to enhance the work of mental health professionals was presented, and essential oils from Young and Living were introduced and applied for ultimate grounding. This was followed by the experiential session in open nature, the Center’s garden. Participants shared that although they never thought they would resume positions as “secret prayer” and the “worrier pose,” they felt so much lighter, happier, more grounded, and loving. Their backaches and shoulder pains melted away with their positive affirmation and movements.
 
Kigali, Rwanda
Our mission to Rwanda took place in collaboration with Aloys Ntezimana, Director of the NGO Self-Employed Youth Organization (SEYO), and Steven Shyaka, Mentee of the Strongest Oak in Kigali. On 4th of July, the ATOP Team met with Nyilinhwaya Faustin, the Minister of Gender and Family Promotion in Rwanda. Although it was a national holiday –Independence Day for Rwanda, a date it shares with the U.S. Independence Day – and all offices were closed, he made a special effort to open his office for our team. He presented us with an update of women’s issues and he elaborated on the recent improvements in gender issues such as the minimum of 50 percent of women required in the parliament. He also shared the ongoing challenges, such as national policy against gender violence, high levels of gender-based violence (GBV), limited knowledge of laws by women, persistence of some negative cultural beliefs such as female genital mutilation (FGM) – which they don’t acknowledge as mutilation because they don’t cut the clitoris but rather stretch both labia for what they believe is the ultimate pleasure for both men and women – as well as rapes of domestic workers. He also emphasized their commitment to the United Nations Millennium Development Goals (MDG)-3, which aims to promote gender equality and empower women while seeking to eradicate gender-based violence, which is an impediment to gender equality and sustainable development. He also emphasized the need for psychological support and ended by inviting our team to conduct workshops in collaboration with his office. 
The next day we conducted a workshop at the Youth Employment Generation office in Nyagatare, which is affiliated with the Rwanda Minister of Youth and engages in reproductive health, HIV education, sewing and other vocational trainings, and nurturing entrepreneurship.
The goals of this agency are peacebuilding, patriotism, national reconciliation, and sustainable development. We had more than 100 participants. Unfortunately, 44.9 percent Rwandese are living below the poverty line, and the majority are young people. Principles of conflict transformation, emotional intelligence, forgiveness, and restorative justice were introduced and reinforced, and this was followed by chakra balancing, energetic healing exercises, essential oils, and Bach flower remedies. Attendees were given bookmarks with non-violent communication (NVC) messages, as well as earrings. We then were transported via motorcycles to the Youth Business Center. There were 48 men and women attending this workshop, and we shared the Seven Habits of Highly Effective Leaders (Steven Covey, 1998), emotional intelligence, work ethics, and values. The team was joined by Michele Merkel, MS, and Stu Merkel, MPH, MBA; their contribution was extremely valuable, especially because of the addition of the male perspective in leadership.
DR CONGO
Few countries have seen the amount of violence that the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has seen in the past decades. Since 1996 the fourth largest African state has seen wars with its neighbors, civil wars, and other forms of violence that have proliferated immense poverty and famine, an AIDS/HIV epidemic, increasing rape rates and gender intolerance. The International Rescue Committee estimated that over 5.4 million people have died from the prolonged conflict, that Nicholas D. Kristof of the New York Times says is being “ignored” by the international community. The vicious cycle of hate and fear seems almost unbreakable for the citizens of the DRC.
Our organization,　The Association for Trauma Outreach & Prevention　(ATOP) of Meaningful World, a New York based international organization affiliated with DPI of the United Nations, devoted to fostering a, just, peaceful, and meaningful world, has collaborated with many organizations to bring rehabilitation programs to Sierra Leone in March of 2009, and over 29 other humanitarian empowerment, educational, and rehabilitation programs around the world including Haiti. Our mission to DR Congo will focus on the city of Bukavu, home to nearly half a million people, including 500 displaced children. We are collaborating with the Peace Center there, as well as Université de la Paix, refugee centers, and hospitals in the area. We will be working with vulnerable groups of children, women who were raped in the war, refugees and older adults. We have the experience and expertise to make a difference. ATOP team members that will be traveling to Congo are: Dr. Ani Kalayjian – Founder and President of ATOP. Dr. Kalayjian has devoted her life to bringing healing to those who have survived the devastation of disaster. Dr Isidore A. Udoh is a postdoctoral fellow at the HIV Center for Clinical and Behavioral Studies at the New York State Psychiatric Institute and Columbia University, and Jennifer De Mucci – Vice President of ATOP, holds a Master’s degree in psychology.
Our goals are to help survivors heal their emotional and psychospiritual wounds resulting from years of armed conflict, poverty, discrimination, and displacement. We aim to help surviving communities understand the impact of the past on their present through education, healing groups, and self-healing. We will train psychologist, social workers, nurses and other health care practitioners. This helps create educated and healthy communities that are able to transform generationally transmitted trauma by cultivating a new world view, train and educate high school teachers and students to nurture non-violence in their respective communities, and foster communal dialogue for conflict transformation and peace-building through practicing forgiveness. We also plan to help mobilize communities, facilitating healthy partnerships that build bridges of diversity through common values centered on the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
We need your generous spirit! Please help us make a difference in in the lives of hundreds of people. Your generous donations are vital to make this ATOP of Meaningfulworld humanitarian outreach project a success. Our first team will depart June 29th 2013.
Alternative ways to donate...
Donations can be made via check or Pay-Pal (see www.meaningfulworld.com for more details). Checks should be made out to ATOP and mailed to ATOP 135 Cedar St, Cliffside Park, NJ 07010.

story:
SES Baton Club

These 20 cute second graders are learning to twirl batons for free, but many can't afford to buy twirling shoes or a costume for their April 20th competition.

When my 8yo daughter wanted to join a baton twirling team, I got the idea to start one at her school. At first it was a little selfish. Starting the club would save me the hassle of driving her to a neighboring town to pay another teacher for her to twirl. Then, I thought of how many kids at her school don't get to do fun stuff like baton, dance, karate or Scouts because over 75% of the families at her school are low-income and simply can't afford extra activities.

It didn't take much to get the Principle's green light to start the club and the membership jumped to 20 girls in only a few days. I volunteer my time to teach the club and the only expense has been for each girl to buy a $20 baton.

 

What the girls need:

  • $200 Contest Enrtry fees ($10 per girl)
  • $1100 In Step Twirling Shoes ($55 per pair)
  • $700 Team Costume ($35 each)
  • And additional funds will buy each girl a team T-shirt

 

Our Perk may be humble, but the joy you bring to these girls will be worth it.

If we don't meet the $2000 goal, we will use the funds to offset the cost of less expensive costumes and shoes and I will pay the contest entry fees out of my pocket.

Twirling Makes an Impact!

Baton twirling made me a better person. Not only did I learn self-discipline, teamwork, coordination, and sportsmanship, but I made life-long friends from all over the country. I want to pass that experience on to these precious girls who wouldn't otherwise get the opportunity.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know there are a lot of campaigns to consider, so even if you can't add us to your funding list, please help spread the word with Indiegogo's share tools.

story:
Our Story >>

After the death of our three year old son Gavin, we knew we wanted to give other kids like Gavin, who are dealing with life altering illnesses/disabilities, the same amazing life Gavin had.  In 2010 we welcomed home Angela to join Adam, myself and our older daughter Madison. Angela is diagnoised with cerebal palsy and 1p36 deletion syndrome.  Soon after we adopted Jayden who suffered traumatic brain injury and we currently are in the process of finalizing are youngest daughters adoption.

Learn more about our story here.

We want all our kids to grow up knowing that they can do anything they put their minds to and that they deserve to have the same opportunities and experiences as other kids their age.

Angela is a girl on a mission.  She wants to move and be independent.  Sadly, most of her equipment holds her high off the ground which leaves her no access to her toys or siblings.  She get very frustrated and we often spend our days bringing the world to her -- We want Angela to be able to GO TO her world.

What We Need >>

We would like to purchase a few items.  The first is a chair called the ZipZac which will cost about $1200.  The chair will allow Angela to sit on the floor and reach her toys as well as be able to access big wheels to push herself around the house!  The second item is a Special Tomato Seat which will cost around $500.  This seat will allow us to put Angela in other chairs besides her wheelchair, like the movies or out to eat -- even a jogger so she can go on runs with her daddy! The remaining amount of funds would go towards some homeopathic treatments we are currently pursuing which are not covered by medical insurance.

The Bottom Line >>

I have never been one to ask for money.   But this is not just giving money, this is about changing Angela's life for the better.  This little girl has so much potential and we will do anything to help her reach it!  I've learned that sometimes we have to go outside out comfort zone to be the advocate our kids need us to be!

story:
Dear friend,

If you had the power to change the world, would you hold back? Each and every one of us possesses that power, yet we often underestimate the impact our small contributions can make. It is up to us to decide how we invest this power, and more importantly, with whom we invest it. I write this letter to you in the hopes that you will invest in my cause.

My name is Oscar Perales, I am fifteen years old, and I have a goal. Since the 6th grade, I have been a proud member of the class of 2015 at YES Prep Southeast Middle School and High School. YES Prep is a public charter school that aims to prepare low-income students to enter and graduate from college. This year, as a sophomore, I had the opportunity to apply to the School for Ethics and Global Leadership- SEGL. SEGL is a semester long program in Washington D.C. focused on helping students like me develop the skills necessary for becoming successful leaders not just locally, but globally through courses, lectures, and interaction with politicians and professors. SEGL will prepare me to become this type of leader by not only challenging me academically but also helping me meet global leaders. With perhaps a little luck and a lot of hard work, I was accepted into SEGL for the fall of 2013. I received a great deal of direct financial aid from SEGL, but in order to fulfill my “personal and community contribution” component of the financial award agreement, I am working with partners to raise the remainder of the tuition.  So here I am, and I need your help.

You’ve heard my story, and I trust that you will support my cause by donating whatever you can. I’m asking that you invest your power with me because your contributions can make a difference, and they will be greatly appreciated. Lastly, even if you cannot donate at this time, please pass this note and web address to a friend, neighbor, or someone that might be interested in supporting my endeavor.  Please tell them my story and how they can contribute to my cause.

Thank you,

Oscar Perales

story:
100 kids with a different future

My name is Margaret. When I arrived in Colombia for a 4 week volunteering program in 2012, I was shocked to discover how many children could not read, and how this was directly related to future participation in gang violence, teenage pregnancy and the ongoing cycle of poverty. So much so that I decided I couldn't sit back and not do anything. 

18 months and a lot of generous support later we are at the point of opening our third
library. In collaboration with Fundacion Afrocaribe, with a team of social workers and psychologists, and some great volunteers we are supporting over 100 children on their journey to become readers, and to change their paths in life. But 100 isn't enough. There are 1000's more children in Cartagena who need our help. But we can't do it alone and need your support now more than ever.

         

This October and November we want to raise $8000. That's enough to put 100 children through our literacy program.

Our literacy programs help:

  1. Children that live in residential care and have no family
  2. Children that have been removed from their family due to abuse or neglect or have been voluntarily placed in care by a parent concerned for their safety
  3. Children who live in extreme poverty, often with illiterate parents, who have missed years of school

$80 to turn a life around

It costs $80 (£50) to fund a child through our literacy program. 

What $80 covers for us:

  • 6 month program with 4 hours of literacy coaching a week
  • Additional one-on-one practice reading sessions
  • Psychologist and social worker support
  • Entry to our well stocked library of children's stories and educational games.
  • Their very own learn-to-read book and practice book
  • Access to pencils, pens, coloured pencils, scissors etc for class activities
  • A safe place to spend time (off the streets)

We want to be able to put 100 more children through our programs. Please help us to get there. Donate $80 by clicking 'Donate' and selecting $80. If $80 is a stretch or if you would like to donate more check out our 'Perks' wall to see our other options.

Meet our kids

Diego* is 12. He was recruited into a gang by his father when he was 7 and was an active member for 3 years. When he was 10 he was placed in care where he has spent the last 2 years. His father was murdered just before Christmas.

Myself and other volunteers have been teaching Diego to read for over 10 months now. At the moment he is reading me the Colombian football star - Falcao's biography. It's an adult level book and I could not be more proud. Reading and writing will allow him to finish school and fulfill his dream of joining the police force.

His options without being able to read and write are far dimmer. He could sell items on the streets at barely enough to survive or alternatively join a gang who offer "a family" and a way to make money.

Wendy* is 13. She lives with her mum and 2 brothers and sisters. Her contact with positive male adults is very limited. Her neighbourhood is plagued by young male gangs. She started on our program in May and is making great strides to improve her reading and writing and subsequently her grades at school. The social workers and psychologist are also helping teach values like respect, self-esteem, peace and friendship. 

Her options without being able to read are limited to working in local shops or selling fruit or handicrafts to tourists. With more than 1 in 5 Colombain girls pregnant before 18 this is also a likely scenario with many girls using sex as a way of fulfilling their desire for attention.

*Names changed to protect privacy

There are 1000s more children like Diego and Wendy in Cartagena alone. Please help us to be able to help them by donating as much as you can today.

How else can you help?

Your support needn't stop at a donation. There are so many other ways you can help.

  • Share this campaign. Facebook, email, old fashioned face to face conversations. The more people who know about the campaign the more children we can help
  • Get fundraising. The money raised from a classic office cake bake, or 10k race could go so far in Cartagena
  • Volunteer. We need people on the ground and remotely, for everything from fundraising, to reading with the kids. Contact margaretobrien77@yahoo.com.au to find out more about the opportunities available.

What our volunteers/supporters say:

"The social gaps in Colombia are huge and unfortunately far too many children are denied adequate education. Giving children the opportunity to read is also giving them the opportunity to cope with life and the chance to create a good future. Spending a few hours in one of these libraries and talking to the children gives you a better understanding of this than all reports and figures you can get hold of. These children love reading, they want to learn and they understand the importance of reading. So let’s work together to give them the opportunity to gain this essential life skill." Karin Lager, Sweden

'Helping these kids to read opens the doors to so many opportunities for them! They can get an education, immerse themselves in books and express themselves through writing! It's a brilliant project!' Becca Todd, England

'Teaching these kids how to read is of one the greatest experience I had. They are just so keen to learn and improve themselves. So this project opens a complete new world for them with more education and probably a way more better future!' Ole Chillt, Germany

'Creating the opportunity for the children to befriend books and words and giving them the courage and confidence to read for themselves and out loud to others is an incredible life skill. This will allow them to grow in themselves and have life long benefits. 

A quote from a favourite children's story of mine is: "The more that you read, the more things you will know. The more you learn the more places you go." Dr Seuss "I can read with my eyes shut"' Julia Wickham, England

"Literacy opens doors that would ordinarily be closed for these kids. It gives them a future filled with possibilities. That is why my family are supporting "100 kids - Let's Help Them Read" Melanie Berry, Australia

"The pen is certainly mightier than the sword. The ability to read and write should be a basic skill for everyone. To think that so many children can be given these very powerful and life changing skills by sharing just the smallest amount of your own good fortune is a complete no brainer. I certainly come from a lucky country where we take so much for granted. Stop, be thankful of what you have and help change a life." Ainslee Cox, Australia

story:
Short Summary

Red Umbrella Project is a New York based peer-led group that works to amplify the voices of those who work in the sex trades through creative programming and legislative and policy advocacy. We are an executive member of the No Condoms as Evidence Coalition, an alliance of advocacy groups and resource providers from many different backgrounds united to pass the No Condoms as Evidence Bill through the NY State Legislature. We want to bring our experiences from this campaign to the Desiree Alliance Conference, a conference in Las Vegas dedicated "to provide leadership and create space for sex workers and supporters to come together to advocate for human, labor and civil rights for all workers in the sex industry." We believe the drawbacks and successes of both our campaign and the coalition-building that made it possible provide fundamental knowledge for any advocacy group for those in the sex trades.

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous contribution will help fund the travel expenses for members of Red Umbrella Project to travel to Las Vegas and present at the conference. We have raised enough money to cover most of our expenses but we need additional funds for:

-plane tickets for three

-food for three

-other expenses such as public transportation within the city and lodging for three

And it will not go unrewarded! Here are the incentives we are excited to offer for your giving:

-3 issues of $pread Magazine

-"Cooking in Heels" by Ceyenne Doroshow

-Introductory year-long subscription to literary journal "Prose & Lore"

The Impact

Those people who work within the sex trades are among the most marginalized members of our communities. The stigma and criminalization of the sex trades contributes to and facilitates economic, mental, physical, and social violence against those who work within them, especially when the workers already experience other extreme forms of oppression such as poverty, racism, transphobia, homophobia, and more. The NYPD practice of using condoms as evidence of prostitution is a prime example of this dynamic, and we have so far succeeded in having the District Attorneys of Nassau and King County in New York issue directives to their prosecutors and police officers to no longer use this practice. We further hope to pass the No Condoms as Evidence Bill, which will make the practice illegal within New York.

By funding our participation in the Desiree Conference, you will be helping us provide the information that advocacy groups for those in the sex trades need to start their own campaigns on ending their state or city's practice of using condoms as evidence, as well as more general information on how to form alliances with groups that advocate around issues other than sex work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/RedUmbrellaProjectNYC

Follow us on Twitter (@RedUPNYC) and Tumblr: http://redupnyc.org/

NY residents can register to have a postcard, illustrated with a true story of a person targeted by the practice of condoms as evidence, sent to their state representatives: http://www.redumbrellaproject.org/nycondom/#comics
story_txt:
Short Summary
Red Umbrella Project is a New York based peer-led group that works to amplify the voices of those who work in the sex trades through creative programming and legislative and policy advocacy. We are an executive member of the No Condoms as Evidence Coalition, an alliance of advocacy groups and resource providers from many different backgrounds united to pass the No Condoms as Evidence Bill through the NY State Legislature. We want to bring our experiences from this campaign to the Desiree Alliance Conference, a conference in Las Vegas dedicated "to provide leadership and create space for sex workers and supporters to come together to advocate for human, labor and civil rights for all workers in the sex industry." We believe the drawbacks and successes of both our campaign and the coalition-building that made it possible provide fundamental knowledge for any advocacy group for those in the sex trades.


What We Need & What You Get
Your generous contribution will help fund the travel expenses for members of Red Umbrella Project to travel to Las Vegas and present at the conference. We have raised enough money to cover most of our expenses but we need additional funds for:
-plane tickets for three
-food for three
-other expenses such as public transportation within the city and lodging for threeAnd it will not go unrewarded! Here are the incentives we are excited to offer for your giving:

story:
January 13th-14th | Gainesville, FL | Free Admission | SwampCon.org

HAPPY HALLOWEEN! Celebrate with these reduced tiers!!

  • Buck-aneer (Variants 1 and 2): lowered from $35 to now $30!!
  • Smooth Sailor: lowered from $50 to now $40!!
  • Cunning Captain: lowered from $200 to now $100!!

SwampCon is an annual, multi-media convention held in Gainesville, Florida on the University of Florida campus. Our convention celebrates many genres, including anime, sci-fi, tabletop, video games, and more. It is absolutely free to attend!

For this year's event, we've set our sights for the sea. Our theme, SwampCon: Voyage, captures the spirit of adventure as we sail into uncharted territory. Climb aboard for high seas adventure and brace yourself for new experiences. It's a pirate's life for me!

SwampCon: Voyage will be held January 13th-14th, 2018 and run all day for both days. It will be hosted at the J. Wayne Reitz Union on the University of Florida campus.

Some of our main attractions for this year include:

  • Fanmade Vocaloid Hologram Concert
  • SwampCon Drag Show, featuring local performers
  • Gator Anime’s Maid Cafe
  • Poi Performance
  • Panels presented on a myriad of topics
  • Special media guest appearances including voice actors, internet personalities, and industry guests
  • Vendors and artists offering merchandise and art for sale

For seven years now, SwampCon has been a convention with zero cost for admission. Each year we grow in size and take on more roles, and as a result, we rely on more funding from sponsorships and donors like you!

All income donated to our event will be used to help run SwampCon: Voyage and allow us to continue making improvements on our programming and overall features.

Contributions will go toward funding:

  • Our lovely convention guides, prints, and merchandise that you see the day of the convention!
  • Special guests! With more support, we can invite more lovely guests!
  • Prizes and support for our wonderful contests and events!
  • Food and supplies for our fantastic and hard-working volunteer staff!

As a show of our thanks for your donations, we offer several rewards listed as perks:

  • Credits in Programming: Your name will be mentioned on our website, social media, our convention guide, and in the credits to the Vocaloid Hologram Concert.
  • Bountiful Buttons: You will receive our beautiful 2.25" buttons with original artwork from the SwampCon Design Team!
  • Arrrrr't Print: You will receive 4x6 prints of original artwork from the SwampCon Design Team!
  • Seaworthy Stickers: You will receive stickers featuring original artwork from the SwampCon Design Team, with capabilities to stick them anywhere you want.
  • Official SwampCon: Voyage T-Shirt: One of our savory t-shirts will be reserved for you to pick up at the con! Although we will be selling them at the con, supplies are limited, so act now! T-Shirts come in sizes S, M, L, XL, 2XL, and 3XL. Please email swampconfundraising@gmail.com with your size preference after you donate.
  • VIP Seating at Main Events: You will be granted access to limited VIP seating at some of our Main Events including the Drag Show, Maid Cafe, and Special Guest Panels.
  • Access to Convention Break Room: You will be able to visit our special break room during the convention. Inside there will be free food and drink and a place to relax after spending hours exploring SwampCon's events and panels.

  • Commissioned Digital Art: Commissions are offered by the SwampCon Design Team and are done on one level. After donating, please indicate your top two preferred artists. If one of our artists has filled up with commissions already, we will default to your second choice. Please email swampconfundraising@gmail.com with your choices after you donate. (Please note that this is for a digital commission only and you will not receive a physical version.)

Our artists this year along with samples of their work:

Gabriella Fagundez

Martha Felts

Ariel Terrazas

Emily Tran

Melissa Soco

Riley Mixson

E

SwampCon is organized by college students who devote their time and effort to making a free, enjoyable, and exhilarating convention. Each year we learn more about planning, how we can improve, and what you, the donors and attendees, love about SwampCon the most!

We make SwampCon for you, and it is your support that drives us forward and keeps us dedicated.

For any questions, comments, or concerns, please email swampconfundraising@gmail.com

story:
In 2013 the Youth Organizing Institute (YOI) turns 4 years old.   

What is YOI?

Short answer: YOI is a popular education leadership development program for high school age students.  We provide trainings on the policies that impact young people and how to organize to create change. In the past 3 years, over 100 Triangle teens have participated in our trainings and we have helped to mobilize hundreds of young people to speak-out in support of equity in public schools.

 

Why YOI?

Youth of color, LGBTQ youth, and poor and working class youth are under attack in public schools. Wake County has one of the highest suspension rates in the country. In Orange County students of color are 17x more likely to get suspended than white students for non violent crimes, such as cell phone use.  What's the solution?  Student Power!  When young people identify and name their problems, and are offered the tools, resources, and space to create solutions - the result is transformative.  In the legacy of SNCC (Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committe) and following Ella Baker's leadership development models, the Youth Organizing Institute believes in elevating the collective voices and power of young people.

 

This Summer

We will train 15 Triangle-based youth, ages 13-18 in a popular education-style curriculum that focuses on political education & leadership development. 

We will establish a year long inter-generational mentorship program for graduates.

We will strategize and plan to launch a campaign for a MORATORIUM on Out of School Suspensions

We will Put the Brakes on the School-to-Prison Pipeline.

 

To meet our goals we need your help!

Funds donated will help us:
• Increase the number of students we can accept into the summer program

• Enhance our summer program by taking a trip to the International Civil Rights Museum and Beloved Community Center in Greensboro

• Develop peer education around the school-to-prison pipeline and school push-out,

• Sustain our campaign for a Moratorium on out of-school suspensions by providing stipends to youth organizers.

Check out some of the Recent Accomplishments of our graduates on our website 

Our History/Legacy (on our blog)

 

 

 

Testimonials from YOI Graduates

      

Qasima Wideman    Beatrice Galdamez          Molly McDonough

"We who believe in freedom cannot rest until it comes"

In the spirit of Ella Baker We need your help to keep this program alive! 

Thank you for your support!  Your donation is a commitment to young people as they become leaders and visionaries in our communities.
