story:
Humans love stories. Sharing stories connects us, human to human, regardless of our differences.  We need your help so we can introduce our unique tool of multilingual stories to people who need and can use them: libraries, students of languages of all ages, and, maybe, you.

How?  You buy a book, we give a book. 

You buy more books, we give more books.

An international group of volunteer illustrators, writers and visual storytellers (ASLTales.net) have worked for years to match masterful written language with visual story telling and American Sign Language on a DVD with 10 different spoken translations, creating beautifully illustrated classics with modern twists or for special viewers.  We now have 4 different stories, ready to go, including Susan Schaller's retelling of The Boy Who Cried Wolf. 

"We adore your books. These are a perfect fit for my classes,... unlike other materials, they teach about the importance of culture ... your ASL storybooks are a great resource."
- M.I., Mother and teacher, Illinois
Aesop, Susan Schaller, et al., Trillium, a non-profit (and you) can all work together to give the community our new book-DVD version of A Boy Who Cried Wolf.  By using eyes and ears with a physical language, spoken translations, a written text and illustrations, we can now share stories in different language at once, and learn from each other.

"Thanks & please keep the books coming! They're gorgeous, ... inspiring, and as a tri-lingual family the language options are much appreciated."
- S.K., a mother from Seattle
We have a stack of book/DVDs waiting for good homes.  We need to buy more and get them to those who would love them for their literacy, storytelling or classroom, along with our support materials, like comics, activity books and resources from fans who are already building bridges between different language groups. 

"The children love learning language this way." 
-C.C., Maine, daycare provider
Your donation will fund the development of new materials, with Masami Kiyono's artwork, cover transportation costs, and help us organize events to build community, encouraging new storytellers from multiple languages.

See the perks to start getting and giving multilingual stories, making a new story: our story.

story:
"When you get really good at something as difficult as jiu jitsu, it makes everything in your life better" - J.Rogan

**********************************

We hope this campaign makes it in front of the right people. 

Fight Family exists for one reason - to bring value to everything we encounter.

If we are able to fund these mats with everyone's help we will attempt to do as many positive and creative things with the mats as possible, and we will document their journey in a transparent online business model so that everyone who donates can not only follow, but participate in.

This is our first attempt at raising funds via crowd-sourcing, and we are both nervous and interested in seeing what happens.  We feel like this campaign has the potential to be a catalyst for similar ventures, and we would certainly appreciate the help spreading the word in trying to get this in front of anyone who might want to be part of it.

We want to offer you something different if you decide to participate. This is your money going to work (along with ours) and we want to be able to show you exactly what happens to the money. 

So, we are going to have a series of fund raising goals, and if you help us raise the funds you will be able to watch your funds in our "Fight Family's Transparent Business Discussion Group" on Facebook where we will open the books on the projects for you to see.  Here, you will be able to participate in conversations with other supporters, and have a say in all future projects we do.

This will be as much of a learning experience as it will be a way for like-minded individuals to connect and come up with powerful ideas.

We wanted to do this project ourselves, but financially is was currently out of the range that we could afford comfortably, and the school program is starting the first week of October 2013.  So we want to include anyone who decides to donate to be part of the ownership process.  By demanding transparency of ourselves, we can share the experience with everyone via our discussion group.  Your input would also be welcomed here.

Once you donate you simply ask to join the group and will be accepted. 

***************************************

Those in the Brazilian jiu-jitsu and martial arts community already know the benefits of practicing martial arts.  It is good for health, confidence, honesty, logical thinking, creative problem solving, discipline... the list of benefits seems to have no boundary. 

Yet programs like this have yet to be really studied.

We have the support of a local University that wants its grad students to study this program in action. We have plenty of legitimate Brazilian Jiu Jiu instructors willing to help the program operate (Note many BJJ schools charge upwards of $200 per month.  The students of this program will be receiving top flight instruction). 

What we don't have, is the mats.

The more mats we can afford the more students we can accommodate, with the ideal amount being the $22,468 mentioned in the video (enough for a solid amount of students per class).  If we don't reach this goal we will buy less mats (what we can afford on our own if we have to).  

But we hope that with your help we will not just afford to buy these mats, but other program enhancements as well.

1) We need mats - the more money we have the more mats we will get and the more students we can accommodate. 

2) We would love to be able to afford jiu jitsu gis (uniforms) for the students, or at least offer them at a discount.  If we exceed our goal this will be part of phase two.

3) We will take any funds raised above and beyond the needed goal, and invest them back into the program.  We will use the Fight Family's Transparent Business Discussion Group to find the best way to spend any possible additional funds, and your voice will be part of it if you donate.

Please keep in mind that Indiegogo will take a % of whatever we raise, so exceeding the goal is better.   

This is an experiment, a opportunity, and a learning experience for everyone involved. We offer up transparency in return for trust in the idea, as well as some pretty sweet perks, including Fight Family's first product, the Academy-sized artist's print on canvas. Please help spread the word! 

Thank you!

Yours, 

Fight Family

story:
Help Me Achieve My Dream Job

Many of you know that I discovered Waldorf Education when Enid was 3 years old. From then on, it became my mission to get her into a Waldorf school and explore becoming a Waldorf Handwork Teacher myself. Who wouldn't love knitting, crocheting, sewing... all... day... long?

This year I was accepted into the 8th Cycle of the Applied Arts Program at the Fiber Craft Studio, which is located at the Threefold Educational Center in Chestnut Ridge, NY. The problem is the tuition isn't cheap and like with most folks, I don't have unlimited funds. My $200 scholarship grant doesn't stretch far into the more than $3000 of tuition each year... and that's not including dorm fees, travel, and food! 

I have scrimped and managed to save enough to start my training, but now I'm asking for your help. I will not fully be able to share the magnitude of thanks I'd like to give for those that help me along the way.

On top of that, I've been working as Handwork Assistant at Enid's school, which is measly hours/pay. As sad as I make it sound, it's an opportunity I couldn't let pass by.

What I Need & What You Get

  • During this first phase, I'm hoping to work towards the goal of only $650, but don't let that dampen your donation.  If I reach my goal or go beyond it, I only lose 4%. If not, the man brings me down by 9%.
  • When you contribute, you will receive a handmade "perk" (see right side)!! Unfortunately, these will not be available before the holidays 2013.
  • Not only do I, but Enid also appreciates your support... she's dying for me to be at her school more!

The Impact

I believe that handwork is beneficial and too often forgotten in today’s society, especially in regards to children. People have forgotten how to use their hands to create useful objects, and I'd like to be part of shepherding a new generation through handwork. (no yarn pun intended)

Handwork helps balance the intellectual and movement activities of children. Students experience the ups and downs of creating things on their own. Handwork strengthens concentration, dexterity, and hand-eye coordination, plus it enhances math skills through counting and measuring. And of course, it offers a boost in self-confidence that will carry them through in life.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out for my campaign. Share this site or refer others to me!
  • Stand on the street corner and beg on my behalf... okay, maybe not a good idea.
  • Indiegogo offers share tools to make things easier.

Instead of buying me holiday and birthday gifts, please contribute. It's the main item on my wish list!!


And that’s it folks!!
story_txt:
Help Me Achieve My Dream Job

Many of you know that I discovered Waldorf Education when Enid was 3 years old. From then on, it became my mission to get her into a Waldorf school and explore becoming a Waldorf Handwork Teacher myself. Who wouldn't love knitting, crocheting, sewing... all... day... long?
This year I was accepted into the 8th Cycle of the Applied Arts Program at the Fiber Craft Studio, which is located at the Threefold Educational Center in Chestnut Ridge, NY. The problem is the tuition isn't cheap and like with most folks, I don't have unlimited funds. My $200 scholarship grant doesn't stretch far into the more than $3000 of tuition each year... and that's not including dorm fees, travel, and food! 
I have scrimped and managed to save enough to start my training, but now
 I'm asking for your help. I will not fully be able to share the 
magnitude of thanks I'd like to give for those that help me along the 
way. 
On top of that, I've been working as Handwork Assistant at Enid's school, which is measly hours/pay. As sad as I make it sound, it's an opportunity I couldn't let pass by.


What I Need & What You Get

During this first phase, I'm hoping to work towards the goal of only $650, but don't let that dampen your donation.  If I reach my goal or go beyond it, I only lose 4%. If not, the man brings me down by 9%.

When you contribute, you will receive a handmade "perk" (see right side)!! Unfortunately, these will not be available before the holidays 2013.

Not only do I, but Enid also appreciates your support... she's dying for me to be at her school more!

forgotten in today’s society, especially in regards to children. People have forgotten how to use their hands to create useful objects, and I'd like to be part of shepherding a new generation through handwork. (no yarn pun intended)

story:
Short Summary

I am Dr. Justine Marie Shuey. I am a Board Certified Sexologist and AASECT Certified Sexuality Educator with a Doctorate in Human Sexuality and a Masters in Human Sexuality Education. For years I have been helping individuals of all ages expand their knowledge around sexuality and gain confidence in their sexual expression. I present on hundreds of college campuses, medical schools, hospitals, organizations and conferences all over the United States and Canada. 

I want to teach the world about healthy sexuality! Every day college students from all over the United States and Canada reach out to me to schedule sexuality education presentations on their campuses. Unfortunately, most schools are slashing budgets and many student organizations lack the funding to cover the expenses of bringing sex education programming to their campus. The goal of this campaign is to raise funding to help reduce the actual expenses (travel and supplies) of events to make sex education more accessible to college students. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to make more events possible. Every dollar gets us one step closer to providing Sex Education programs on college campuses. The funding will be used to cover the actual expenses (travel and supplies) to make more events possible. While the funding goal for this campaign is set to $500, anything above and beyond that goal will be put towards additional events. 

  • If you donate $15 or more (plus the cost of shipping) you will receive a #1 Tip for Hotter Sex T-Shirt. 
  • If you donate $25 or more I will give you a personal shout out on social media.
  • If you donate $25 or more (plus the cost of shipping) you will receive a 100% premium silicone waterproof vibrator in your choice of 4 styles. 
  • If you donate $69 or more you will receive a a special gift bag with tips for great oral sex, safer sex supplies and flavored lubricant for your oral pleasures. 
  • If you donate $100 or more you will help cover the cost of a hotel room and I will send you a bag of swag filled with sexy samples and a handwritten thank you note and give you a personal shout out on social media.
  • If you donate $250 or more you will help cover the cost of a flight and you will have the opportunity to schedule a personal one-on-one educational session with me via skype or phone, I will send you a bag of swag filled with sexy items and a handwritten thank you note and give you a personal shout out on social media.

We also give away condoms, lubricants, and other safer sex supplies at every event and raffle off awesome prizes to attendees. If your business would like to donate products or services to be given to students at events please contact info@drshuey.com to discuss these opportunities. 

Sex Education Program

College is a time to experiment with academic interests, career choices, and sexual expression. Sexuality is still considered a taboo subject, leaving unanswered questions and perpetuating misconceptions. Dr. Justine Marie Shuey, a highly acclaimed, certified sexuality educator and keynote speaker addresses misinformation head-on while enhancing sexual awareness. Colleges and universities testify that Dr. Shuey encourages students to explore and learn about sexuality in an entertaining, engaging, and informative way.

Presentations are personalized to meet the needs of students and may include these topics and more:

  • Sexual Communication
  • Consent & Sexual Assault Prevention
  • Hook-up Culture / Rape Culture
  • Safer Sex, Contraception, and Abstinence
  • Sexual Decision Making
  • Dating and Healthy Relationships
  • Sexual Behaviors and Sexual Pleasure
  • Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer Issues & Ally Training
  • Polyamory / Non-monogamous Relationships
  • Alternative Sexual Practices / BDSM & Kink
  • Tips, Tricks, and Techniques for great sexual experiences
AND... the opportunity to ask a real sex educator anything about sex! 

What to Expect in a Presentation:

Tasteful and appropriate presentations that combine a unique sensitive tell-it-like-it-is approach with respect for all lifestyles and levels of sexual experience. Dr. Shuey adds a fun twist to teaching edgy topics and honors the culture of the school or hosting organization. Dr. Shuey's presentations are engaging experiences with audience participation that create memorable events and encourage positive sexuality on campuses across the country. Students can expect to see:

  • Puppets & props
  • Audiovisuals, media & images
  • Group icebreakers
  • Interactive activities & games
  • Demonstrations
  • Content that appeals to multiple learning styles
  • Language inclusive of all sexual orientations and gender identities
  • Appropriate content for individuals with all levels of sexual experience
  • Anonymous Q&A session
  • Free condoms, lubricants, and other goodies for students

About Dr. Justine Marie Shuey 

Hailing from the city of brotherly love, Dr. Justine Marie Shuey has always had a passion for human sexuality. She completed her Bachelors degree with a minor in Women & Gender Studies and was accepted to Widener University’s Masters in Human Sexuality Education program before heading to San Francisco to complete a Doctorate in Human Sexuality at the Institute for Advanced Study of Human Sexuality. Dr. Shuey is currently working towards a second doctorate degree (a Ph.D.) in Human Sexuality from Widener University. 

For years Dr. Shuey has been helping individuals of all ages expand their knowledge around sexuality and gain confidence in their sexual expression. Dr. Shuey teaches college Human Sexuality courses at Temple University, Montclair State University, Middlesex County College and Montgomery County Community College. She also presents on hundreds of college campuses, medical schools, hospitals, organizations and conferences all over the United States and Canada. Dr. Shuey provides training to health care professionals and teaches medical students how to incorporate reproductive health exams and sexuality discussions into their practices in a respectful way that eases anxieties.

Recognizing that many instances of school harassment, intimidation and bullying result from anti-gay bias, Dr. Shuey began volunteering with Gay Lesbian Straight Education Network of Central New Jersey as a safe space trainer and was asked to join their Board of Directors. In this role, she trains teachers and raises awareness among students, helping to make schools safe and welcoming environments for all students.

The Impact

Every year I speak to thousands of college students about healthy sexuality, communication, consent, pleasure and more! Your support can help bring sexuality education that is inclusive of all sexual orientations, gender identities and appropriate for individuals with all levels of sexual experience to college students all over the United States and Canada. Past presentations:

Colleges & Universities

  • Brooklyn College (Brooklyn, NY)
  • Brown University (Providence, RI)
  • Bryant University (Smithfield, RI)
  • Bryn Mawr College (Bryn Mawr, PA)
  • California State Polytechnic University (San Luis Obispo, CA)
  • California State University Monterey Bay (Seaside, CA)
  • California State University Northridge (Northridge, CA)
  • Davidson College (Davidson, NC)
  • Delaware County Community College (Downingtown, PA) 
  • Drexel University (Philadelphia, PA)
  • Earlham College (Richmond, IN)
  • Eastern Connecticut State University (Willimantic, CT)
  • Florida Institute of Technology (Melbourne, FL)
  • George Washington University (Washington, D.C.)
  • Georgetown University (Washington, D.C.)
  • Goldey-Beacom College (Wilmington, DE)
  • Harrisburg Area Community College (Lebanon, PA)
  • Haverford College (Haverford, PA)
  • Institute for Advanced Study of Human Sexuality (San Francisco, CA)
  • Johnson & Wales University (Charlotte, NC)
  • Marymount Manhattan College (Manhattan, NY)
  • Mercer County Community College (West Windsor, NJ)
  • Middlesex County College (Edison, NJ)
  • Monmouth University (Long Branch, NJ)
  • Montclair State University (Montclair, NJ)
  • Montgomery County Community College (Blue Bell, PA)
  • Nassau Community College (Garden City, NY)
  • North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (Greensboro, NC)
  • Norwalk Community College (Norwalk, CT)
  • Ohio University (Athens, OH)
  • Rider University (Lawrenceville, NJ)
  • Rutgers University (New Brunswick, NJ)
  • Rutgers University (Newark, NJ)
  • Rutgers University (Piscataway, NJ)
  • Seminole State College of Florida (Sanford, FL)
  • Shepherd University (Shepherdstown, WV)
  • St. Mary's College of Maryland (St Marys City, MD)
  • Stetson University (DeLand, FL)
  • Swarthmore College (Swarthmore, PA)
  • Syracuse University (Syracuse, NY)
  • Temple University (Philadelphia, PA)
  • Trinity College (Hartford, CT)
  • University of Arkansas (Fayetteville, AR)
  • University of California Berkeley (Berkeley, CA)
  • University of California Davis (Davis, CA)
  • University of California Riverside (Riverside, CA)
  • University of California Santa Barbara (Santa Barbara, CA)
  • University of Connecticut (Storrs, CT)
  • University of Lethbridge (Lethbridge, AB, Canada) 
  • University of Pennsylvania (Philadelphia, PA)
  • University of Pittsburgh (Pittsburgh, PA)
  • University of Redlands (Redlands, CA)
  • University of Virginia (Charlottesville, VA)
  • West Chester University (West Chester PA)
  • Widener University (Chester, PA)

Medical Schools & Hospitals

  • Albert Einstein College of Medicine (Bronx, NY)
  • Cooper University Hospital (Camden, NJ)
  • Mount Sinai School of Medicine (New York, NY)
  • Morehouse School of Medicine (Atlanta, GA) 
  • New Jersey Medical School (Newark, NJ)
  • New Jersey School of Osteopathic Medicine (Stratford, NJ)
  • Ohio University Heritage College of Osteopathic Medicine (Athens, OH)
  • Overlook Hospital (Summit, NJ)
  • Robert Wood Johnson Medical School (Piscataway, NJ)
  • Rowan University School of Osteopathic Medicine (Stratford, NJ)
  • Rutgers Medical School (Piscataway, NJ)
  • Stony Brook University School of Medicine (Stony Brook, NY)
  • West Virginia University School of Medicine (Morgantown, WV)

Conferences

  • American Medical Student Association Empowering Future Physicians Conference - Philadelphia 2013
  • Rutgers University Minority Association of Pre-Health Students Annual Conference 
  • Sex, Love, and Dating Conference: Your A to Z Guide to Everything Intimate at Rutgers University
  • Expanding Teaching Horizons Teacher Expo
  • Coming of Age: Issues of Aging in the LGBT Community 2012 Conference at Mercer County Community College
  • Florida Collegiate Pride Conference at University of South Florida
  • Careers in Sexuality Conference at Widener University
  • North Carolina Housing Officers P.L.A.Y. Day Conference at North Carolina Central University
  • Center for Family Life Education Sexuality Education Conference

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Every dollar helps bring sex education programming to colleges If you can’t contribute today please help us get the word out about this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, tumblr, etc. If you have attended one of my presentations in the past show others the importance of sex education by sending a testimonial to info@drshuey.com. 

    http://drshuey.com

    https://www.facebook.com/doctorshuey

    https://twitter.com/doctorshuey

    http://doctorshuey.tumblr.com/

    http://www.linkedin.com/in/doctorshuey

story:
Hello!

My name is Beth and I have been a primary teacher in San Francisco, California for the past five years. I first visited Cambodia one year ago on holiday and it was love at first sight. Not only is the country strikingly beautiful, but so are the people.  I was amazed at the warmth, friendliness, and contagious smiles that greeted me here.  I wondered how a country that has endured horrors such as genocide could be what seemed like the happiest place on earth.  The Cambodian people are a testament to the courage, beauty, and resilience of the human spirit. Even though I was only able to stay in Cambodia a few days, I knew I would be back and I knew I wanted to help.

Education has taken a major hit in Cambodia since 1975-1979 when all intellectuals and educators were killed during the Pol Pot regime. Almost a third of the population were executed during the era of the Khmer Rouge.  People killed their own people.  Pol Pot thought an agrarian society was utopian.  He held the famers in highest esteem and thought anyone that had too much money was poisoning the system.  He relocated millions of Cambodians from the city centers to the countryside, turning major population centers into ghost towns. The people were tortured and sent to killing fields or placed in prisons, including children and women.  Impossible production demands were placed on people in forced labor camps and people were given little to no food.  Maybe only a few grains of rice per day.  I met a man who said he doesn’t even know his mother’s name. He was taken from her as a small boy and she was killed in the camp.  Many adults who grew up during this time were never given any type of education and some are illiterate in their home language of Khmer.  The country is in the beginning stages of trying to rebuild and recover from this dark era.  Many leaders of the regime have yet to be prosecuted.  Saws and hammers are literally heard all day long from the early dawn hours as people reconstruct their identities and their communities.

 Children sell to help their families, some who live on just pennies per day.  A good wage in Cambodia is about one hundred American dollars per month, but this is rare. Therefore all family members need to pitch in to help support the family, many of which are very large.  The first time I was here, a small child of about five came to me as I walked through pub street telling me he needed money for formula for his baby brother (a common story). Not taking, “No” for an answer, he latched himself onto my leg and continued to walk around on my leg for at least twenty minutes.  As much as my heart ached to help the children, I knew that giving handouts to them and purchasing their items was not the way to truly help.  Instead, these practices are actually counterproductive.  If children are able to make a good living begging and selling their items in the street, they will see no need to go to school and this will only continue their reliance on the tourists and perpetuate the cycle of poverty.

Sexual slavery of children is another grim reality in Cambodia.  A friend of mine was working for Childsafe, helping to break up the rings of child prostitution, risking his own life to do so.  He helped save a boy of eight and found a girl of age four placed in a bag, her life taken.  Providing a good education will open up worlds of opportunities for people that may feel they have no other way to survive.

Who are we?

Painting Smiles is a small organization of individuals committed to improving the level of education in rural Cambodia, specifically in the area of Otres Village, outside of Sihanoukville on the southwestern coast of Cambodia.  Painting Smiles was started by Shaun Prest in 2011.  Shaun first traveled to Cambodia 7 years ago with a friend on motorbikes, delivering coloring books and felt pens to children in rural areas and it is from here that the name of the school, "Painting Smiles" originated.  The school's mission is to provide quality free English instruction to over 250 students, grades K-5.  A new initiative we are organizing is a mobile classroom that will visit rural areas of Cambodia that do not have any access to education. Instead, we will bring the education to them!

Your contributions to the Painting Smiles school will have a direct and measurable impact on the families in Cambodia.  Your donations will extend the reach of our school to families with no access to English education.  Your contributions will enable us to take resources to those in need, improving their future opportunities. 

At the Painting Smiles site, we have stacks of notebooks from “lost children” who come to school a few times, then are sucked into employment. With engaging resources, a Khmer outreach worker and extra-curricular activities, we hope to offer them something that enhances their life experience. 

Cost

We are currently operating on less than $120 per month (a recent income from local businesses) which is only enough to cover the cost of a Khmer teacher and translator salary. The Western teachers are unpaid and volunteer-only, paying their own costs.  We are seeking funds for the following resources:

- truck for a MOBILE CLASSROOM to reach the people in rural Sihanoukville who do not have access to English education

- fuel for the mobile classroom

-whiteboard for the mobile classroom

- clipboards for the mobile classroom

-  English reading books

-  student instructional workbooks, forty cents each

-  colored pencils

-  felt pens

-  pencils

-  scissors

-  glue

-  electric pencil sharpener

-  blender to make healthy snacks

-  paper, three dollars per ream

-  poster paper

-  paint

-  paintbrushes

-  individual student white boards and markers or sheet protectors to make our own

- soap, toothpaste, and toothbrushes to teach about hygiene

- balls and playground equipment

- a brick wall for games

-general maintenance for the building

My name is
Beth and I have been a primary teacher in San Francisco, California for the
past five years. I first visited Cambodia one year ago on holiday and it was
love at first sight. Not only is the country strikingly beautiful, but so are
the people.  I was amazed at the warmth, friendliness, and contagious
smiles that greeted me here.  I wondered
how a country that has endured horrors such as genocide could be what seemed
like the happiest place on earth.  The
Cambodian people are a testament to the courage, beauty, and resilience of the
human spirit. Even though I was only able to stay in Cambodia a few days, I
knew I would be back and I knew I wanted to help. 
Education
has taken a major hit in Cambodia since 1975-1979 when all intellectuals and
educators were killed during the Pol Pot regime. Almost a third of the
population were executed during the era of the Khmer Rouge.  People killed their own people.  Pol Pot thought an agrarian society was
utopian.  He held the famers in highest
esteem and thought anyone that had too much money was poisoning the
system.  He relocated millions of
Cambodians from the city centers to the countryside, turning major population
centers into ghost towns. The people were tortured and sent to killing fields or
placed in prisons, including children and women.  Impossible production demands were placed on
people in forced labor camps and people were given little to no food.  Maybe only a few grains of rice per day.  I met a man who said he doesn’t even know his
mother’s name. He was taken from her as a small boy and she was killed in the
camp.  Many adults who grew up during
this time were never given any type of education and some are illiterate in
their home language of Khmer.  The
country is in the beginning stages of trying to rebuild and recover from this
dark era.  Many leaders of the regime
have yet to be prosecuted.  Saws and
hammers are literally heard all day long from the early dawn hours as people
reconstruct their identities and their communities.
 Children sell to help their families, some who
live on just pennies per day.  A good wage in Cambodia is about one hundred American dollars per
month, but this is rare. Therefore all family members need to pitch in to help
support the family, many of which are very large.  The first time I was here, a small child of
about five came to me as I walked through pub street telling me he needed money
for formula for his baby brother (a common story). Not taking, “No” for an
answer, he latched himself onto my leg and continued to walk around on my leg
for at least twenty minutes.  As much as
my heart ached to help the children, I knew that giving handouts to them and
purchasing their items was not the way to truly help.  Instead, these practices are actually counterproductive.
 If children are able to make a good living begging and selling their
items in the street, they will see no need to go to school and this will only
continue their reliance on the tourists and perpetuate the cycle of poverty. 
Sexual
slavery of children is another grim reality in Cambodia.  A friend of mine was working for Childsafe,
helping to break up the rings of child prostitution, risking his own life to do
so.  He helped save a boy of eight and
found a girl of age four placed in a bag, her life taken.  Providing a good education will open up
worlds of opportunities for people that may feel they have no other way to
survive.
Who are we?
Painting
Smiles is a small organization of individuals committed to improving the level
of education in rural Cambodia, specifically in the area of Otres Village,
outside of Sihanoukville on the southwestern coast of Cambodia.  Painting
Smiles was started by Shaun Prest in 2011.  Shaun first traveled to
Cambodia 7 years ago with a friend on motorbikes, delivering coloring books and felt pens to
children in rural areas and it is from here that the name of the school,
"Painting Smiles" originated.  The school's mission is to
provide quality free English instruction to over 250 students, grades K-5.
 A new initiative we are organizing is a mobile classroom that
will visit rural areas of Cambodia that do not have any access to education.
Instead, we will bring the education to them!
Your
contributions to the Painting Smiles school will have a direct and measurable
impact on the families in Cambodia.  Your
donations will extend the reach of our school to families with no access to
English education.  Your contributions
will enable us to take resources to those in need, improving their future opportunities. 
At the Painting Smiles site, we have stacks of
notebooks from “lost children” who come to school a few times, then are sucked into employment. With engaging resources, a Khmer outreach worker and extra-curricular activities, we hope to offer them something that enhances their life experience. 
Cost
We are
currently operating on less than $120 per month (a recent income from local businesses) which is only enough to cover the cost of a Khmer teacher and translator salary. The Western teachers are unpaid and
volunteer-only, paying their own costs. 
We are seeking funds for the following resources:
- truck for a MOBILE CLASSROOM to reach the people in rural Sihanoukville who do not have access to English education
- fuel for the mobile classroom
-whiteboard for the mobile classroom
- clipboards for the mobile classroom
- 
English
reading books
- 
student
instructional workbooks, forty cents each
- 
colored
pencils
- 
felt
pens
- 
pencils
- 
scissors
- 
glue
- 
electric
pencil sharpener 
- 
blender
to make healthy snacks
- 
paper,
three dollars per ream
- 
poster
paper
- 
paint
- 
paintbrushes
- 
individual
student white boards and markers or sheet protectors to make our own

- soap, toothpaste, and toothbrushes to teach about hygiene
- balls and playground equipment
- a brick wall for games
-general maintenance for the building

story:
When I was in Belize in January, I met a lovely young local "man" named Eloy Young at the tiny airport while I was waiting for the plane to come home. We sat together for about 40 minutes, and he talked to me the whole time. He's a sweet, sweet 18-year-old guy who knows how to build boats, and is trying really hard to make a life for himself on an island that offers very little in terms of educational and career options. He tried to join the British Army last month, but they stopped responding to his requests, probably due to his limited literacy.

Right now he's very excited because there's a 3-month course he can take to become a tour guide, which would mean he could take tourists out on his boat and show them the Barrier Reef, and snorkel with them. (I did one of those tours myself when I was there, and my tour guide was fantastic!) I want him to have this, but it costs $325, and I just don't make enough money to send him that kind of dough.


So I'm asking my FB friends to contribute to giving a chance for a decent life to one earnest young man, who's dealing with poverty, the loss of both his parents, hunger on a too-regular basis, and very limited options for making a better life. Please make a difference in a Belizean kid's life! (The photo is Eloy, on his beloved boat.) ♥

story:
Fun-raze-ing for ROKPA: The Chop for Charity Campaign 

Having often wondered what it would be like to: 

  1. Never have a bad hair day
  2. Never get my hair stuck in my lipgloss on a windy day
  3. Finally remember what my natural hair colour is 
  4. Roll down the car window and not worry about my hair getting messed up (or blowing in my face) 
  5. Go to a Halloween party dressed as GI Jane, Sigourney Weaver in Alien 3, Homer Simpson, or that chick from Empire Record

I have found myself compelled at this stage in my life to give it a go:SHAVE MY HEAD. However, these aren't the real reasons why I want to take the plunge. On the 8th October 2013, my dearest friend, teacher, and father-figure, Dr. Akong Tulku Rinpoche, tragically passed away. He is the co-founder and president of ROKPA, an international registered charity whose projects focus primarily on education, healthcare, cultural preservation, and environmental conservation. Most of ROKPA's work is currently carried out in Tibetan areas of China, Nepal, South Africa, and Zimbabwe. 

Having endured extreme hardships himself, Akong Rinpoche selflessly dedicated his whole life to helping those in need all around the world, regardless of race, religion or culture. His compassion, loving-kindness, and wisdom was limitless to all. I will be forever grateful for what he has taught me, bestowed upon me; for all his love, encouragement, support, direction, and faith. Therefore, as a small and humble thanks, I would like to raise as much money for ROKPA as possible in order to help keep his legacy alive and to ensure that the all the incredible work he started continues to benefit endless beings. 

To give you a small idea of what your dosh could provide in Tibet, here's a quick break-down of some costs: 

Education 

  • For approx. £112 / $179 / €133 one Tibetan orphan receives a year of primary education, room, and board 
  • For approx. £241 / $386 / €287 one Tibetan orphan receives a year of secondary education, room, and board 
  • For approx. £59 / $94 / €70 ten adults receive adult education (reading and writing) for one year 

Health

  • Approx. £47 / $75 / €55 supports a village clinic for one month 
  • Approx. £305 / $489 / €363 provides a salary for one Tibetan doctor for one year 
  • Approx. £915 / $1,468 / €1,090 provides a hospital bed and physical therapy for a stationary patient for one month  

Culture

  • Approx. £30 / $48 / €35 provides a salary of a stone sculptor for one month
  • Approx. £111 / $178 / €132 allows the salvaging of ten old Tibetan texts
  • Approx. £17,597 / $28,240 / €20,965 allows the construction of one stupa (religious and cultural monument that attracts pilgrims thus stimulating the local economy - huge knock-on effects)

These are just a few examples of how far your money can go (if you would like more details or would like to enquire about a specific project, I will gladly provide more information). I have been secretary of ROKPA Belgium for almost 5 years now and have recently been made a legal administrator. ROKPA is run almost entirely by hard-working and dedicated volunteers; this year, ROKPA volunteers donated 27,770 hours of their time equating to a staggering £757,478 in monetary terms! This is what makes ROKPA unique - the large majority of donations go straight to the projects and aren't wasted on salaries and administration costs. Therefore you know that your donation, whether large or small, is making a difference to someone's life. For example, this year alone ROKPA has helped almost 12,000 people in Tibet. 

So, my fab friends, whether or not you knew Akong Rinpoche, or even if you only know myself and want to support a charitable challenge (or just see me with a skin head - I know a few of you would love to get your hands on those clippers!), please dig deep and donate your hard-earned cash to this worthy cause. If my target of £10,000 is reached, I will gladly (but sadly!) get rid of the goldilocks. I know this is a high target but if I'm going to go ahead with the chop, I would like a decent amount of dosh to be raised in order to support enough projects. Plus, Rinpoche always said, "Only the impossible is worth doing" so here we go! 

And if you don't have the means to financially contribute, have no fear, there are other ways you can help. ROKPA is always in need of peeps willing to fundraise, to donate their time, skills, and expertise. Just drop me a line for more info: alana@rokpa.org or contact your national ROKPA branch (ROKPA is active in 20 countries - find your national contact person on our website!). And please help me get the word out and make some noise about my "Fun-raze-ing for ROKPA: The Chop for Charity Campaign"!

Last but not least, you can find all the latest info on other ROKPA campaigns, events, info etc on our ROKPA Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/ROKPA.org?ref=hl or on our website: http://www.rokpa.org/world/ 

I THANK YOU in advance for all your donations and support. You are saving and changing lives! 

Love and hugs,

Alana Craigen

story:
Please Read Ibra's story 

This is my story :  Ebrima Cham

My is Ebrima Cham, and I am currently an international student at National Chung Hsing University in Taiwan (R.OC). I am from The Gambia, West Africa; I was admitted and awarded a scholarship to pursue a bachelor degree of International Agribusiness in Taiwan the September, 2012 intake. This opportunity to me was a dream come true for me because growing up from an extended family   of which my Dad has to deal with three wives and up to more than 20 ( twenty) sons and daughters was not an easy life for me. I suffered among others a life of deprivation and a lack of “something”.

However, my love for education since I was young seems to be the only tool that can help me out and make a good change. I worked hard and maintained an impressive academic performance throughout my schooling. It was obvious that if I wish to achieve my dream of pursuing higher education and escaping the poverty trap (as well as helping others out) , I needed to be strong and hard on my studies to stand a better chance a better chance to win a scholarship.  After I graduated from high school in 2010, I started seeking for scholarships from every angle. While I was searching for scholarships, I decided to dedicate myself to teaching as an unqualified teacher in my country, The Gambia. Even though I was not with any college degree or teaching certificate, my outstanding credential from High school helped me got the job. I was also able to concurrently do some part-time teaching contracts where I have to visit students at their houses and get them prepared for final exams. Through that I was able to earn some money to help myself and my mum during those trial times.

In September 2012, I took the offer of a scholarship to come to study in Taiwan. The scholarship covers my tuition fees and a monthly stipend of NTD 8000 (= US$ 267) from which I have to pay for accommodation, health insurances, books (and other stationary) and other expenses which are not covered by the scholarship.  I knew the amount of the monthly stipend will not be enough to support me but I took the offer anyway because, from the scholarship’s description it was stated that the monthly awarded stipend begins from NTD 8000  to NTD 20,000 which will be awarded depending on academic performance. I thought that with my little pocket money saved from teaching can somehow support me during the first academic year, and if I study hard and emerged  with good grade my stipend will be increase so that I can support myself for the following academic years. The academic year is now gone but it was really hard. I sometime can only eat one meal a day, it was really a serious condition but lived with hopes.

The renewal of the scholarship was announced on the 5th June and we suffered severe scholarship cuts. (The reasons being attributed to a low budget): http://www.oia.nchu.edu.tw/chinese/01_news/02_n...
To my dismay, instead of an increase, the stipend were cut, and I fall under those with NTD 4000 which is really discouraging because that amount cannot even pay for house rent, not to mention food, books, health insurance fees and renewal fees of my Alien Resident Certificate (ARC). Also I cannot do any form of part-time job here to help me support myself and continue my studies. Many of the other affected international students whose countries are not far from Taiwan, especially those from Thailand have started going back home because they cannot sustain it. The living cost is so expensive in Taiwan. I believe I have come too far to go back to nothing or start from scratch   ; even if I should go back home I cannot afford the flight ticket. I believe with little help , I can continue on my studies so as to keep working on my dream of contributing to the improvement of food security in my country as well as help myself and family. I also want to be a poet whose writings may help change some negative concepts mentality that is causes most of our problems  such as the irony of “ The more children, the more fortunate”.

story:
Hey guys,

 

As you know ill be going to school in september. School comes with a lot of expences and i was hoping i could reach out to all of you to help me out. if youre able and willing please donate some money to my college career. please and thank you. =)



A photograph captures a piece of life in a frozen frame; a memory that you can see physically with your eyes, share with the world and pass down generation after generation. 

Knowing that I can capture a piece of life by pressing a button is breath taking. A picture can change anyone’s life. It can make someone feel better about who they are and shows they are changing even if they can’t or don't notice. Its cliché, but a picture can mean a thousand words and a thousand things. For those reasons, I want to be a photographer. I enjoy making people happy and feel good about who they are and how they look, especially when they doubted they’d look good. I am fulfilled knowing that I can and have made a difference.

It not "Just a picture" its "A piece of life frozen in time forever."

story:
→ Stretch Goals & Updates
→ What is Pixelles
→ Funding Needs
→ Changing Culture
→ More Ways to Help
→ Media & Partnerships
→ Pixelles Team
→ Contact


Update 4: Final days! Final stretch goals announced: Pixelles ++ & Petites II
Update 3: Go, go, Teacade! Another stretch: Mentorship Meet & Greet II!
Update 2: Pixelles Petites is happening! Next stretch goal: Teacade.
Update 1: Thank you! + Stretch Goals announced!


Pixelles is a non-profit initiative committed to helping more women make and change games. We're based in Montreal, and have already succeeded in building a supportive community of game creators, both hobbyist and professional. Based out of Montreal, our activities are roughly divided into two categories:

Games as artistic medium: 
Through our annual incubator, game jams, and monthly workshops, we help women realize their own potential at making whatever game they can dream of. As an art form, games benefit from having more diverse voices contributing to its growth. 

Games as career:
Through our 1:1 mentorship program and socials, we help women network to gain role models and career advice. Our monthly workshops encourage them to learn new game development skills such as programming languages, 3d modelling, game design, and much more...


Learn more about our methods, incubator, results, and how to start your own women-in-games initiatives by watching Tanya's talk at the Game Developer's Conference and reading our post-mortem of the Pixelles Game Incubator (2013).


Pixelles is entirely volunteer-based and organized in our free time outside of our day jobs. However, while we try to keep costs down to a minimum, our programs do require some money to function. Your donation will go to:

  • TWO Pixelles Game Incubators (2015 & 2016)
    Our incubator program is a free, 6 week workshop where at 10+ women of diverse backgrounds and experiences make their first video game. No previous experience or programming knowledge required!  At the end, we have a community showcase to celebrate our newest makers. Many of our alumna have gone on to making more games, leading game jams, and even joining the games industry!  (Note: Games made during our incubator belong 100% to the participants. We don't make any money nor ask for anything in return.)


  • Non-profit registration fees with the Quebec government
    In order to be a government listed as a non-profit organization we'll have to register with Quebec and pay fees to them. Having NPO status will allow us to file for grants, obtain sponsorship with companies in Montreal, and ensure Pixelles' future beyond its  founders.

  • Taxes, fees and perk costs
    This includes Indiegogo campaign related costs such as printing, shipping/mailing, perks, & fees.

Any extra funds will cover more workshops, programs, equipment & tools licenses! We're also looking into buying old laptops to make our activities more accessible since not everyone has or can afford one. We'd love to also be able to pay our workshop leaders & helpers a small honorarium for their time. 

If we don't reach our goal, as much money as possible will go into paying for at least one run of Pixelles Game Incubator. This program is one of our most important and successful ways we empower women in Montreal to make games.


Impact is always hard to quantify, but we believe that our projects have a rippling effect in the community. It’s capable of literally changing the culture and conversation around games, from Montreal outwards.

It’s about more than women making game prototypes. The Pixelles Game Incubator is about each participant creating a game of her very own design, literally empowering her to express herself in a form that she's never before experienced, from the seed of an idea to a real piece of software, even if she's never programmed anything before.

The common perception of game creation as a male-dominated activity is thereby challenged by her existence, game-making journey, and experiences. Our showcase and participation in various cultural organizations/activities in Montreal, in turn, raises awareness in the community about women-in-games & the accessibility of becoming a maker.

Further, many participants find that their passion for game development is sparked by this creative success, and go on to make many more games:

↑ One year later, we asked the women from the first Pixelles Game Incubator what they’ve been up to in games. Since making their first game with us, they've gone on to creating even more games, participating in jams & competitions, working professionally, and becoming more involved in the games community. 
Plus, check out what our 2nd incubator alumna have done, in only one year (hint: it's even more!):



Our mentorship program connects aspiring and junior women in game dev experienced folks in their dream jobs. It's more than just a role model — we foster help personal relationships that which clear the haze around joining the industry, support their job search, and contribute towards breaking the glass ceiling. So far, we've helped quite a few women get jobs in both AAA and indie studios, with many more on their way!


Our workshops, socials, and jams all bring us together in our shared love of game creation. We've seen our activities grow larger as empowered members, in turn, inspire and teach new ones. 

We look forward to the day when these initiatives aren't need in order for everyone or anyone to make games. With your help, we can help empower more women to create, learn, & become a part of the games community, as well as, work towards changing the culture surrounding games.


It started with the Pixelles Game Incubator I, in January 2013. From there, Pixelles has grown to host monthly workshops, jams, socials, & 1:1 mentoring for women who want to join the games industry.

Rebecca Cohen-Palacios, Director & Co-Founder
She made her first teach-typing, cat game in the Hand Eye Society's "Difference Engine Initiative 2" (similar to Pixelles' incubator). That experience led her to make many more games and go on to working at Ubisoft as a UI artist & developer.


Tanya X. Short, Director & Co-Founder
She has worked as a professional game designer for many years. She is now Creative Director of her own indie studio, Kitfox Games, and speaks about procedural generation design to anyone who will listen.



The Pixelles Game Incubator III is currently in-progress and is coordinated, for the first time, by alumna of past incubators (2013/2014):

Kim Hoang
Love Love Hill Collective comics artist & alt games maker 		Alicia Fortier
Game Designer at Ubisoft & veteran jammer


Pixelles is made by possible by our many allies, partners, friends, family,  developers, mentors, workshop volunteers, participants, and aspiring women-in-games. Give a high-five to our amazing mentors and join our Facebook group. Many of our activities, around the community events, and knowledge-sharing takes place there.


Anyone can help; no matter your gender, orientation, or age. If you'd like to do any of the things below please e-mail us at info@pixelles.ca! Thank you!

  • Become an industry mentor
    Are you experienced in the industry or as an indie developer? Volunteer your time by becoming an individual mentor and help guide a future woman in games. You can even do this long-distance! 

  • Donate a laptop
    Not everyone can afford to have a laptop for our workshop, game jams, or other activities. By donating equipment, you're helping make our programs more accessible! Have equipment to donate? Send an email to info@pixelles.ca.

  • In Montreal: Give a workshop
    Every month, we organize a free workshop for the community; open to everyone of all ages, gender, and skill level. You can teach a small group how to code, draw, 3D model, Twine, pixel art, anything really! In the past, we've done weird Unity/SketchUp, dating sims, 3D modelling, Twine, & Unity programming.

  • In Montreal: Help out at a workshop
    It's only natural for people to get stuck or lost at a workshop. For this we have helpers who go around and make sure things run smoothly while the teacher is teaching. You'll answer questions, orient folks in the right direction, & provide encouragement. 


Since 2013, we've partnered with, organized activities, & been supported by a number of organizations around Montreal. We're looking forward to working with lots more in the future!


 We've also been written about in the media!
  • Empowerment through development: The Pixelles Game Incubator
  • Pixelles Montréal lance un nouvel incubateur pour les femmes dans l’univers du jeu vidéo
  • Leading Ladies: Amazing Indie Games Made by Women
  • Pixelles: Calling All Game Designing Ladies
  • Pixelles Montreal: Ces filles qui créent leur jeu video
  • Lady-Players, ten Women Become First-Time Game-Makers in a Montreal Incubator
  • Pixelles Postmortem: How to Increase Game Diversity NOW
  • Pixelles pour encourager les femmes à créer des jeux-vidéos
  • Inclusive Initiatives in the Indie Game Community
  • Shattered Planet: an Interview with Tanya X. Short
  • Pixelles: Bringing Women Into the World of Indie Gaming
  • WIGI & Pixelles Social
  • Indiedependent Incubating Indies in Dublin and Montreal
  • La view pas si rose des créatrices
  • Interview with Tanya Short, head of Kitfox Games and Coordinator at Pixelles

For any questions, volunteering, potential partnerships, or media requests, please email Tanya & Rebecca at info@pixelles.ca. We'll get back to you as soon as possible!
story_txt:
→ Stretch Goals & Updates→ What is Pixelles→ Funding Needs→ Changing Culture→ More Ways to Help→ Media & Partnerships→ Pixelles Team→ Contact


Update 4: Final days! Final stretch goals announced: Pixelles ++ & Petites IIUpdate 3: Go, go, Teacade! Another stretch: Mentorship Meet & Greet II!Update 2: Pixelles Petites is happening! Next stretch goal: Teacade.Update 1: Thank you! + Stretch Goals announced!




Pixelles is a non-profit initiative committed to helping more women make and change games. We're based in Montreal, and have already succeeded in building a supportive community of game creators, both hobbyist and professional. Based out of Montreal, our activities are roughly divided into two categories:
Games as artistic medium: Through our annual incubator, game jams, and monthly workshops, we help women realize their own potential at making whatever game they can dream of. As an art form, games benefit from having more diverse voices contributing to its growth. 
Games as career:Through our 1:1 mentorship program and socials, we help women network to gain role models and career advice. Our monthly workshops encourage them to learn new game development skills such as programming languages, 3d modelling, game design, and much more...




Learn more about our methods, incubator, results, and how to start your own women-in-games initiatives by watching Tanya's talk at the Game Developer's Conference and reading our post-mortem of the Pixelles Game Incubator (2013).


Pixelles is entirely volunteer-based and organized in our free time outside of our day jobs. However, while we try to keep costs down to a minimum, our programs do require some money to function. Your donation will go to:


TWO Pixelles Game Incubators (2015 & 2016)Our incubator program is a free, 6 week workshop where at 10+ women of diverse backgrounds and experiences make their first video game. No previous experience or programming knowledge required!  At the end, we have a community showcase to celebrate our newest makers. Many of our alumna have gone on to making more games, leading game jams, and even joining the games industry!  (Note: Games made during our incubator belong 100% to the participants. We don't make any money nor ask for anything in return.)



Non-profit registration fees with the Quebec government
	In order to be a government listed as a non-profit organization we'll have to register with Quebec and pay fees to them. Having NPO status will allow us to file for grants, obtain sponsorship with companies in Montreal, and ensure Pixelles' future beyond its  founders.	

 Taxes, fees and perk costs
	This includes Indiegogo campaign related costs such as printing, shipping/mailing, perks, & fees.




Any extra funds will cover more workshops, programs, equipment & tools licenses! We're also looking into buying old laptops to make our activities more accessible since not everyone has or can afford one. We'd love to also be able to pay our workshop leaders & helpers a small honorarium for their time. 
If we don't reach our goal, as much money as possible will go into paying for at least one run of Pixelles Game Incubator. This program is one of our most important and successful ways we empower women in Montreal to make games.


Impact is always hard to quantify, but we believe that our projects have a rippling effect in the community. It’s capable of literally changing the culture and conversation around games, from Montreal outwards.


It’s about more than women making game prototypes. The Pixelles Game Incubator is about each participant creating a game of her very own design, literally empowering her to express herself in a form that she's never before experienced, from the seed of an idea to a real piece of software, even if she's never programmed anything before.
The common perception of game creation as a male-dominated activity is thereby challenged by her existence, game-making journey, and experiences. Our showcase and participation in various cultural organizations/activities in Montreal, in turn, raises awareness in the community about women-in-games & the accessibility of becoming a maker.
Further, many participants find that their passion for game development is sparked by this creative success, and go on to make many more games:



↑ One year later, we asked the women from the first Pixelles Game Incubator what they’ve been up to in games. Since making their first game with us, they've gone on to creating even more games, participating in jams & competitions, working professionally, and becoming more involved in the games community. Plus, check out what our 2nd incubator alumna have done, in only one year (hint: it's even more!):


Our mentorship program connects aspiring and junior women in game dev experienced folks in their dream jobs. It's more than just a role model — we foster help personal relationships that which clear the haze around joining the industry, support their job search, and contribute towards breaking the glass ceiling. So far, we've helped quite a few women get jobs in both AAA and indie studios, with many more on their way!



Our workshops, socials, and jams all bring us together in our shared love of game creation. We've seen our activities grow larger as empowered members, in turn, inspire and teach new ones. 
We look forward to the day when these initiatives aren't need in order for everyone or anyone to make games. With your help, we can help empower more women to create, learn, & become a part of the games community, as well as, work towards changing the culture surrounding games.

Alicia Fortier

story:
Last year, the East Bay Poetry Summit brought over twenty poets from around the country to the East Bay for five nights of poetry, conversation, community-building, karaoke, dancing, drinking, flirting. Friendships were forged, yelps were howled, and hundreds of folks attended these free events. Read Anna Vitale's take on the Harriet blog here! And Anne Boyer's here!

To celebrate the long tradition of non-instutitional spaces for poetry and writing in the Bay Area, we're bringing the East Bay Poetry Summit back in 2014. And you're invited!

We've invited poets from around the US and Canada to converge on Oakland to give readings, lead conversations, mix cocktails, and teach and learn from each other. Confirmed readers include Will Alexander, Stephen Boyer, Ana Bozicevic, Allison Cobb, Coda (formerly Debbie Hu), R. Erica Doyle, Farnoosh Fathi, Aaron Kunin, Mat LaPorte, K. Silem Mohammad, Feliz Molina, Erin Morrill, Trish Salah, Jennifer Tamayo, Catherine Wagner, Jackie Wang, and Brian Whitener.  More names to come in the coming days.

We are hoping to pay all out of state poets $250 and in-state poets $100 for their travels. We wish it could be more--but this is your chance to directly impact our effort to help these poets travel to the Bay Area. Your generosity will make all the difference, as once again we are not funded by any institutional support! All the readings and events will be absolutely FREE! so any help you can provide would be critical to help these poets with the burden of travel costs.

The summit will launch Wednesday, July 2nd with karaoke at a location TBD.  Readings will happen Thursday night, Friday afternoon and night, Saturday afternoon and night, followed by a party Sunday to celebrate and reminisce. Schedules forthcoming. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!


Official Schedule 


Wednesday, July 2nd

Karaoke at Nick's Lounge | 3218 Adeline St, Berkeley


Thursday, July 3rd

8pm Speakeasy | 604 56th, Oakland
Erin Morrill 
Jackie Wang 
Brian Whitener
Will Alexander


Friday, July 4th

4pm The Long Haul | 3124 Shattuck Ave, Berkeley
Leigh Phillips
Stephen Boyer
Brenda Iijima
Jesus Lasso
Rodney Koeneke

8pm Woolsey Heights | 1628 Woolsey St. Apt. C, Berkeley
Mat Laporte 
Cathy Wagner 
R. Erica Doyle 
Farnoosh Fathi


Saturday, July 5th

4pm Tender Oracle | 531 22nd St, Oakland
Trish Salah
Ana Bozicevic 
Jennifer Tamayo 
Coda Wei (formerly known as Debbie Hu)

8pm Bay Area Public School
K Silem Mohammad 
Allison Cobb
Aaron Kunin
Feliz Lucia Molina


Sunday, July 6th 

BBQ PARTY at David Buuck's house. Contact for location.

Let us know you are coming at our Facebook event page here: https://www.facebook.com/events/717525338293528/

story:
WE NEED YOUR GENEROUS SUPPORT TO INTRODUCE THIS VALUABLE PRODUCT TO THE WORLD…. MORE SUCCESSFUL FUNDRAISING…LESS WORK!  YOU CAN HELP SOLVE A HUGE PROBLEM.

97% of all schools and service groups must fundraise to support themselves and their projects.

Traditional School Fundraising as it is usually done today is an outdated and, often times, dangerous model. We at His Coffee Company have developed a far better way to reach and exceed fundraising goals with our new ONLINE e-commerce program, which is better described as “an on-going Revenue Stream”. More money raised….less work!

His Coffee Company has pioneered a software program that allows us to correct all that is not good about traditional fundraising. We looked at all the common problems associated with traditional fundraising and we addressed them individually, using today’s technology and today’s trends in societal behavior. Please consider the dramatic impact of the following points as we take each challenging aspect of fundraising and present our solution.

Traditional Fundraising usually lasts about two weeks from start to finish (not counting weeks of confusing preparation and follow-up).

His Coffee Co.’s online fundraising, on-going revenue stream, does not require an end date; it does not need one because coffee and tea are a daily commodity, not an "extra" in the lives of most people. Unlike wrapping paper, popcorn, or cookie dough etc., people are willing to purchase and repurchase the coffee and tea they drink daily, while supporting the group or loved ones with which they are personally connected. We have developed an online order and reorder system to capture and track all purchases and profits back to the original fundraising organization or individual. Monthly orders, all school year long will far out perform a two week push for the usual fundraising “stuff”.

Traditional fundraising has always required a dedicated organizer or team of organizers to get all the order-taking materials from the vendor to the participants and explain to everyone involved how that program should work….always confusing! When the order taking stops after one or two weeks, the organizer must gather all the forms from the participants, tally them up manually, deposit the checks (hope they don’t bounce) and cash into a special bank account, order and pay for the product from the vendor in advance, wait 4-6 weeks usually, and then receive the bulk order. They must then separate that bulk shipment into the original small orders per participant based on those hand written order forms, re-contact each participant and make sure that each perfectly prepared order is delivered to each participant, who in turn, delivers their orders to those who gave them the original order. Even if all this goes smoothly, the organizers are usually heard saying.. ”Never again”!  This is how traditional school fundraising has been done for over 75 years……it’s time for a change and we have developed the new system!

His Coffee Co. has created a program which is run completely online which facilitates an ongoing revenue production that ELIMINATES the massive work and confusion of the Organizer or team.  NO MORE ordering and distributing paper order forms. NO compiling or deciphering of completed order forms. NO processing personal checks or cash. NO bulk orders from the vendor to sort through. NO personal deliveries by organizer or participants. Now the online order is sent directly to the customer or purchasing supporter in 4-6 days, not the currently accepted 4-6 weeks.  Every person who participates in this new system of revenue production has their own semi-customizable online landing page which automatically links them to the group they are associated with. For example: in a typical school setting, a student and their parents can send an email to all his or her friends and family asking them to support their cause by clicking on their unique landing page which takes the supporter directly to their store.  The invited supporter makes their purchases via their approved and secure credit card. That order will be tracked in our system back to the student/individual/family that sent the email invitation, also tracked back to the class in which they are a member, along to the school that they attend, and even to the His Coffee Independent Sales Representative who may have introduced the on-going revenue program to that school. The school will receive about 35% profit on each online sale. Reorders are also tracked the same way. Reminders and promotions can be sent out to all supporters as often as needed by His Coffee Company. The school or the supporter can also check the auto-reorder option on their original order to reorder. The ONGOING REVENUE STREAM profits are paid to the school on the 10th of the following month for all the sales shipped in the preceding month.

THIS IS WHY WE NEED YOU…

The software program described above is no longer a dream. We have spent the entire year of 2013 and invested over $100,000.00 developing this unique fundraising tool into reality. The potential to change the way schools, groups, and even individual’s raise funds is ready to be presented to the world. We need your help to do that! As with any software dream, in the process of bringing this program to fruition, we've exceeded our budget in order to include as many aspects as necessary to achieve successful fundraising results. In doing so, we've had to invest money into its development which was assigned to the promotion of this incredible tool.  We want to bring this project to the next level. We want to get it out there to help schools, churches, youth groups raise the money they need. The more you generously invest in this pioneering product, the more lives we can touch. Please know you are needed.

Blessings,

Mitch & Lidia

story:
* All proceeds will be going directly to the Dekpor Organization


During fall of 2012, I took part in a study abroad program called Semester at Sea. In 107 days, we sailed around the perimeter of the Atlantic Ocean, visiting 14 different countries on 4 continents, North America, Europe, Africa and South America.

Of all the amazing experiences I got to have on this journey, the single memory that stuck with me most was my visit to Dekpor Village, Ghana. 

As a part of my stay in the village, I got to volunteer as a teacher in the school for a classroom containing Kindergarden-2nd grade students.  Despite the huge smiles on these children’s faces and their eagerness to learn, only about half of them could participate in their classroom exercises, as they didn’t own a pencil. Seeing this unfair limitation to education broke my heart. Yet sadly, this was far from the only limitation that faces the children in Dekpor.


It has now been over two years since I visited the amazing village of Dekpor, but I continue to think about these people every day. So, for the last two years, I have been trying to help these kids in my own small way by asking my family to donate to the Dekpor School Development Organization for my birthday. This year, I am taking it a step further. Instead of birthday presents, birthday cards or Facebook comments, I’d like to invite everyone to donate to join me in helping the children of Dekpor Village. One dollar to them can go such a long way, and one dollar in our society can’t get us much more than a cup of coffee.


I've decided to focus this campaign on the need for both ...health and education of these children, as health is an integral part of being able to learn. There are many important projects that are being done, and you can be a part of making a difference in the life of someone who truly needs your help.

For a list of more Dekpor Village past and current projects, please see the Projects section of the Dekpor School Development Organization Webpage here: http://www.dekporschool.org/Dekpor_School_Devel...

If you'd like to allocate your donation to one of their specific areas of need, please just let me know and I can make sure it happens.

Thank you so much for taking the time to view my campaign, and please help make this birthday wish come true. 

Here's what you can do:

1. Make a donation

2. Share this campaign on social media

3. 'Like' Dekpor School Development Organizaation's Facebook page: www.facebook.com/DekporSchool

4. Help spread the word about this great charity and my campaign however you can!
story_txt:
* All proceeds will be going directly to the Dekpor OrganizationDuring fall of 2012, I took part in a study abroad program called Semester at Sea. In 107 days, we sailed
around the perimeter of the Atlantic Ocean, visiting 14 different countries on 4
continents, North America, Europe, Africa and South America. 
Of all the amazing experiences I got to have on this
journey, the single memory that stuck with me most was my visit to Dekpor Village,
Ghana. 
As a part of my stay in the village, I got to volunteer as a
teacher in the school for a classroom containing Kindergarden-2nd
grade students.  Despite the huge smiles
on these children’s faces and their eagerness to learn, only about half of them
could participate in their classroom exercises, as they didn’t own a pencil.
Seeing this unfair limitation to education broke my heart. Yet sadly, this was
far from the only limitation that faces the children in Dekpor. 
It has now been over two years since I visited the amazing
village of Dekpor, but I continue to think about these people every day. So, for the last two years, I have been trying to help these
kids in my own small way by asking my family to donate to the Dekpor School Development Organization for my birthday. This year, I am taking it a step further. Instead
of birthday presents, birthday cards or Facebook comments, I’d like to invite everyone
to donate to join me in helping the children of Dekpor Village. One dollar to
them can go such a long way, and one dollar in our society can’t get us much
more than a cup of coffee. I've decided to focus this campaign on the need for both ...health and education of these children, as health is an integral part of being able to learn. There are many important projects that are being done, and you can be a part of making a difference in the life of someone who truly needs your help.
For a list of more Dekpor Village past and current projects, please see the Projects section of the Dekpor School Development Organization Webpage here: http://www.dekporschool.org/Dekpor_School_Devel...
If you'd like to allocate your donation to one of their specific areas of need, please just let me know and I can make sure it happens.
Thank you so much for taking the time to view my campaign, and please help make this birthday wish come true. 
Here's what you can do:
1. Make a donation
2. Share this campaign on social media3. 'Like' Dekpor School Development Organizaation's Facebook page: www.facebook.com/DekporSchool4. Help spread the word about this great charity and my campaign however you can!

story:
RGB is an instructional DVD in the art form of card flourishing created by Dom Corrado, Max Galarce, and Conor O'Kane.  In this DVD you will receive explanations for twelve of our best flourishes.  RGB consists of three locations throughout the Chicago area from a forest preserve in the suburbs, the red bricks of an abandoned school, and downtown in the city itself.  There is also a guest appearance by Franky Morales teaching one of his favorite moves: Ginatonic.  There are also many bonus features including three ADDITIONAL bonus moves by Dom, Max, and Conor, as well as unseen performance videos and meetup videos.

MAX:

POLARIS - Created in 2012, a sidewinding packet flourish with a slick closer. 

ANDROMEDA - Created in 2013, a "galactic" cut with a unique grip and flare, ending with a single card rotation to the back of the deck.

STUMBLELINE - Created in 2014, a simpler packet cut where packets "stumble" down the "line" of an isolated packet.

ATLAS - "previously known as Doubleverse" created in 2012, a flourish inspired by my cut "multiverse" that mesmerizes its spectators with its complex motions of single cards around multiple packets

CONOR:

BONDAX - This is my newest move I have on the DVD. It was created after Magic Con after I had been messing with the rotation idea in the beginning for a couple months. 

GOLDCOAST - Created in early 2014, I made this move based on a previous move I had made a few years ago. In this move I integrated a lot of rotating and revolving packets which all come together for a slick closer.

ORBIT - Also created in early 2014, I wanted to make a move with an interesting grip. The name comes from the packet at the end which spins while revolving around the deck.

MYSTERY BOX - I created this move with inspiration from Hector Garcia. The beginning starts with a few complex flips and creates a box, which vanishes as the cards rotate back onto the deck.

DOM:

FILIBUSTER - This card flourish was created shortly after learning the move "Alice" by Tobias Levin, which was a large inspiration towards the flourish. This is one of the longer flourishes on the DVD.

JENGA - This card flourish/display was created during the WKC competition when I had to make my first round entry. It originally had a different display, only flipping one of the packets, but since then I have changed it so two packets now flip. The beginning of the flourish has been modified slightly as well.

OXFORD - A packet card flourish that I created about a week after Magic Con, using inspiration from the convention to create a unique but well-flowing flourish, This flourish was heavily inspired by Oliver Sogard.

DRAGSTER - Dragster is my favorite card flourish of mine to do. This move was created when I thought my flourishes didn't have much flow, so I decided to make a fun, somewhat easy flourish that had a smooth flow.

ALSO BE SURE TO FOLLOW US ON INSTAGRAM AND SUBSCRIBE TO OUR YOUTUBE CHANNELS FOR UPDATES ON THE PROJECT:

@conor0Kane

https://www.youtube.com/user/Conor0Kane

@domc76

https://www.youtube.com/user/domcorrado76
@vanllamax

https://www.youtube.com/user/MGCardistry

story:
My sister, Erin Miller, is studying abroad in Chile for six-months as a part of her education at Syracuse University in New York. She needs to raise $1,000 for basic living expenses and a whopping $17,000 to curb the debt for her tuition. Our goal is to raise $5,000 to take care of some of the expense. How? Through filming a sit-com.

I, Connor Miller, have written a five-episode sit-com that will air on the Pinole Public Access Channel and YouTube. The premise: A young man tries to raise money for his study-abroad tuition through a lemonade stand. Over the next two months, we will be filming this series all over Pinole.

By donating to my sister’s cause, you have the chance to be in the credits of the sitcom, to get a physical copy of the script, or even to make a cameo appearance in one of the episodes. If you are a small business and would like to contribute to the cause, we can place your product or service prominently in an episode.

How do you donate? HERE on Indiegogo, you can pledge whatever amount of money you choose. However, please remember that we only have 60 days to raise $5,000, and the donation period ends on August 11, 2014. All proceeds go to Erin Miller and her living expenses and tuition for her study-abroad trip.

For more information about the sit-com or the fundraiser, please contact me at connor.c.miller@gmail.com. If you are interested in my sister and her adventures abroad, please check out her blog at http://syriouslyerin.wordpress.com/.

Thank you so much, and we look forward to working with you!
